p.seg: The transmission from the lord of the Jiāngzhōu Mansion (Wáng Tōng’s great great great grandfather Wáng Huán 王煥)
were the Decisive Records on the Five Classics in five chapters,
in which the meaning of the discussion of the transmission from the sages and worthies was completely laid out.
The transmission from Sir Mù of Jìnyáng (Wáng Tōng’s great great grandfather Wáng Qiú 王虯, 428-500)
was the Major Discussion on Administration in eight chapters,
in which the Way of the emperors and kings (of old) was laid out.
The transmission from the lord of the Tóngzhōu Mansion (Wáng Tōng’s great grandfather Wáng Yán 王彥)
was the eight chapters of the Minor Discussion of Administration in eight chapters,
in which there is a complete discussion of the achievements of a king and of a hegemon.
The transmission from Sir Xiàn of Ānkāng (Wáng Tōng’s grandfather, died 581)
were the Political Disquisitions on the Ultimate Principles in nine chapters,
in which there is a profound account of the dynamic relations between the Three Factors (Heaven, Earth, Man).
The transmission from the lord of the Mansion of Tóngchuān (Wáng Lōng 王隆 (no dates, Wáng Tōng’s father, much respected scholar, often referred to as the lord of the Tóngchuān Mansion.)
were the The Essentials of Rise and Fall in seven chapters
in which there was a clear account of the successes and failures during the Six Dynasties.
I, for my insignificant part, have managed to survey these accomplished teachings
and have worked carefully on them for nine years.
I have ingested the main ideas of my forebears
and I have investigated the mindset of Confucius.
The affairs of Heaven and of Man,
and the Way of the emperors and kings (of old),
have become abundantly clear to me!”
The Master said to (his favourite young disciple) Dǒng Cháng:
“When I was about to work on the Primal Classic,
I investigated the various histories and disquisitions,
but they did not provide sufficient evidence for my points. LY3.9
Then I got the Ultimate Political Disquisitions.
When I wanted to continue the Songs
I checked the collected writings and the historical records,
but these did not provide sufficient evidence for my points, LY3.9
then I got the Discussions of Historical Variations.
When I wanted to write the Sequel to the Documents
I referred back to the various memoirs
but these did not provide sufficient evidence for my points, LY3.9
then I got the Major Discussion of Political Administration.”
Dǒng Cháng said:
“What you got, our Master,
was presumably what you were after in this.”
The Master said:
“Indeed.”
The Master said to Xuē Shōu 薛收 (591 - 624, one of Wáng Tōng’s main disciples):
“In ancient times the Sage (i.e. Confucius) transmitted three works of history:
when he transmitted the Documents
the régime of the Sovereigns and Kings was fully presented;
therefore, when one sought these things one would find all;
When he transmitted the Songs
the reasons for the rise and fall of things became strikingly manifest;
therefore, when one studied these things one would find all.
When he transmitted the Annals
the signs of what is deviant and what is correct were made clear
therefore, when one was investigating the Annals everything is on target.
As for these three works,
they all come from the archivists/recorders
but they must not be mixed together.
Therefore the Sage (Confucius) kept them apart.”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“As I look at the tradition after Sīmǎ Qiān and Bān Gù,
how the transmitted works (on history) were multifarious indeed!
The Way of the Sovereigns and Kings surely remained in the dark and was less than clear!
The designs of Heaven and that of Man, (BHT 21.143.2)
these surely have nothing to do with each other and do not coincide!
When (the historians) were setting up principles they were so much at variance(cēn) and disunited!
When they set out matters they were so confused and devoid of guiding principle!”
When the Master heard unexpectedly about unrest at Jiāngdū
he was in tears and, all excited, he said:
“The people have been appalled by political unrest for a long time.
Maybe Heaven will open up for a new turn as from Yáo and Shùn
but I will have nothing to do with this.
It is all fate.”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“It is a long time since the Way does not prevail over the times.
What am I supposed to do?”
Dǒng Cháng said:
“Only after you, Master, have reverted from Qín to Jìn
and after you have made your abode in Fènyáng,
only then the cosmological and moral principles
have each found their proper place.”
Xuē Shōu asked:
“May I ask about the Sequel to the Documents beginning its account in Hàn times,
why is that?”
The Master replied:
“The depravity of the Six competing Warring states,
and the cruelty that led to the ruin of the Qín
these I cannot bear to hear of.
Where should I be looking for those Ultimate Reasons?
When the Hàn unified All Under Heaven
they removed cruelty and impropriety
and together with the people they made a new beginning:
that surely raised their awareness of things to a new level(?????)!”
Xuē Shōu went on (pointing out an apparent incoherence of approach):
“May I ask, then, why the Sequel to the Songs provides detail about (all of) the Six Dynasties?
Why was that?”
The Master said:
“Is this because the 300 (poems) of Confucius from beginning to end belonged to the Zhōu?”
Xuē Shōu said:
“Yes.”
The Master said:
“How would I dare to compare myself to Confucius?!
But when it came to the point of rise or fall
I kept thinking about it forever.
Therefore as to giving a complete account of the Six Dynasties
I made a report of it."
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“For three hundred years there have not been proper rewards and punishments in All Under Heaven,
was it not natural enough that the Primal Classic came up?”
Xuē Shōu said:
“Yes, but as for it beginning with Huì of Jìn (reigned AD 290-306),
why is that?”
The Master said:
“In ancient times, when the enlightened Kings were in charge,
was there any irregularity in rewards and punishments?
The commendations and the reprobations in the Primal Classic,
these were replacements for the rewards and the punishments.
Then All Under Heaven was going to have no ruler
rewards and punishments were surely remaining unclear!”
Xuē Shōu said:
“First now I understand that when there is good order in the world
then it is the Sage who is in charge,
and when there is chaos in the world
it is the Sage who is in an inferior position.
When the Sage succeeds then rewards and punishments are properly practised;
and when the Sage fails to win through, approbation and reprobation (in the history books) arises.
Then the Ultimate Imperial Order is re-established
and this civilised pattern LYxxx is not lost.
That is surely a profound point!
Having bowed twice he (Xuē Shōu) left
and he reported the matter to Dǒng Cháng.
Dǒng Cháng said (echoing Confucius himself):
“After the death of Confucius the civilised pattern is now found here!”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
Imposing indeed is the Way of (the (Duke of?)) Zhōu and of Confucius
It (their Way) surely is the work of a supernatural power!
If one conforms to this way, that is auspicious;
if one goes against that way, that is inauspicious.
When, in the Primal Classic the Master transmitted the matter of the huángshǐ period (371-409) (unification of the area north of the Yellow River)
he heaved a sigh on that occasion.
His entourage did not quite understand what was going on,
but (the Master’s younger brother) Wáng Níng commented:
“When our Master’s sighed
he was presumably sighing about fate.
The Documents have it:
“The decrees of Heaven are not mechanically constant
they turn only to those who are possessed of virtue.
(Even) the virtue of the Róng and of the Dí barbarians (i.e. the barbarian rulers of the Northern Wèi and their likes)
the black-haired (Chinese) people cherished/identified with it.
How would the Three Agencies of Heaven, Earth and Man reject them (and not let them succeed???)?”
When the Master heard about this he said (to his brother Wáng Níng):
“Níng,
you do understand decreed fate!”
When the Master was in Cháng Ān

Yáng Sù Yáng Sù 楊素 (died 606, poet and general, also known as “Sir” Yuè 越公, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors), Sū Kuí (Suí official under 隋煬帝), and Lǐ Délín (Suí dynasty official, died 591) all begged for an interview.
The Master had discussions with them
but when he returned he wore a worried expression on his face.
A follower asked the Master about this.
The Master said:
(Yáng) Sù discussed with me all day
and he discussed administration but did not get through to its progressive change,
(Sū) Kuí discussed with me all day,
and he discussed songs all day, but he did not get through to dignified elegance.
(Lǐ) Délín discussed with me all day,
and he discussed dignified form, but he did not get through to underlying principles.
The follower went on:
“So what were you worried about?"
The Master said:
“That is not something you would understand.
You people are all prime practitioners of court discussion.
But now when you discuss administration, you do not get through to progressive change,
in that way there is no ritual propriety in All Under Heaven;
when you discuss songs you do not to get through to the dignified elegance,
that is for there to be no music in All Under Heaven;
when you discuss proper form you do not get through to the underlying principles,
that is for there to be no real proper form in All Under Heaven.
The way of the true King, wherefrom will it then arise? (There is no basis for it!)
That is why I looked worried.
When the follower had withdrawn the Master took the lute and strummed the Tāng tune.
The entourage all wetted their lapels with tears.
The Master said:
“Some do their thing quietly,
others do their thing looking for profit,
still others do their thing fearing what would happen if they didn’t.
When it comes to their achieving success,
they may be the same,
but when you examine their moral virtue, then they differ widely.
Jiǎ Qióng studied the Documents (Sequel) and got to the Fate of Huán Róng,
and he commented:
“How imposing are emperor Guāng’s and emperor Míng’s achievements.
It is Heaven that was keeping an eye on him:
He was sure to end up as a paragon of polite deference!”[Something rotten here. I have not sorted this one out yet.]
Fán Shīxuān 繁師玄 (no dates, late Suí man of letters) was about to write his Record of the Northern Qí,
and he told the Master about his plans.
The Master said:
and the Master would not accept it,
saying:
“Since I live on millet as gruel and coarse grain
your book is no use to me.”

The Master answered him in terms of the Wine Announcement and the Hóngfàn about the Three Virtues (of straightness, decisiveness, and flexible victoriousness, as proper guidance for culinary matters).”
The Master said:
“The petty man, unless prodded, shows no firmness of attitude,
unless he sees profit he is not encouraged to action.”
Qīng Jūnliàng asked about what is disgraceful.
The Master said:
“When one‘s words do not hit the mark
or when one’s actions are not meticulously well-considered,
then that is disgrace.”
The Master said:
“When transformation has gone through all the nine changes,
then the Way of the King surely shines forth!
Thus when music has reached the relevant nine changes,
then the spirit of earnestness takes a unified form.”
Péi Xī 裴晞 (WT’s uncle-in-law, mentioned in 資治通鑑 for an appointment in AD 618) said:
“What does that mean?”
The Master said:
“As for music
it illustrates achievement.
And as for illustrating achievement nothing is more efficient than giving it a material form
and letting it flow through melody.
The transformations worked by the King are visible at every stage.
Thus when the Sháo ritual music (of the emperor Shùn) was brought to completion
the munificence of Shùn reached what moves and what grows;
the nests of the magpie
one could peep into by looking down at it,
and why should a phoenix bird have to hide at that point (when the Sháo is properly performed)?”
The Master said:
The extravagant expense of the Fēngshàn sacrifice
is by no means an ancient one.
It is just designed to pervade All Under Heaven,
surely, it is a matter of the (innovative, universalist) extravagance of the Qín and the Hàn.”
The Master said:
“Someone easily pleased is bound to be often grieved;
someone prone to generosity is bound to be prone to taking things away.”
The Master said:
“In a state in which there is no pardon from the law
punishments are bound to be even;
in a state that takes in many taxes (and has corresponding expenses)
the private wealth in it is bound to be reduced.”
The Master said:
“Those pure of heart constantly enjoy freedom from want;
those who are greedy constantly worry about insufficiency of means.”
The Master said:

“If Dù Rúhuì 杜如晦 (AD 585-630, served under the Suí, then senior minister in the early Táng administration, often mentioned together with Fāng Yuánlíng 房元齡, famous scholar official who in the end failed to play any important role) had met an enlightened king
then in the eyes of the the common people he would surely have become like ‘Heaven’!”
(The disciples) Dǒng Cháng, Fāng Yuánlíng and Jiǎ Qióng asked:
“What do you mean?”
The Master said:
“Spring brings things forth,
summer makes them grow,
in autumn one harvests them in,
in winter one stores them up.
When a father gets to be a proper father,
when a son gets to be a proper son,
when a ruler gets to be a proper ruler
when a minister gets to be a proper minister,
then the myriad categories of beings find their proper places.
What the common people have daily use for but do not understand,
this Mr Dù sees as his responsibility>moral concern,
should one not consider him to be like ‘Heaven’?
I have long investigated this person:
his regard is all blurred,
his spirit is all dazzled.
It is as if this man was fully aware of the changing times,
and because he worried about not meeting a true ruler that he turned out as he did.”
(WT’s brother) Wáng Níng said:
“When, in the course of one year, Shùn inspected all the Five Mountains,
the state had no special expenses, the people were not exhausted by labour.
Why was that?”
The Master said:
“This was for no other reason
than that it was the proper Way.
When one’s guards are few then one’s demands on public funds are few.”
The Master said:
“Since the royal state had its Airs (the Royal Airs in the Songs),
were the Son of Heaven (ruler of the royal state) and the feudal lords equals?
Who was the reason for this?
It was the fault of King Yōu of Zhōu 周幽王(reigned 782 － 771 BC, whose degenerate rule marked the end of the Western Zhōu period).
Thus things began (to go wrong) with the Shǔlí (first item in the Royal Airs),
and at this point the Way of dignified elegance came to a stop.”
The Master said:
“When the Five Agents are not out of harmony with each other
then the true king can systematically establish the rites;
when the Four Supernatural Animals (麟,鳳,龜,龍) are properly reared
then the true king can create ritual music.”
The Master travelled to a temple to Confucius.
When he left he sang:
‘Great words these:
the ruler be a ruler, the minister a minister;
the father be a father, the son a son;
the elder brother an elder brother, the younger brother a younger brother;
the husband be a husband, the wife a wife.
This is all because of the Master’s strength.
Surely this combined its charismatic power with the tàijí ‘Ultimate’,
and it is in line with with the Way of the Spirits!”
Wáng Xiàoyì 王孝逸 (Suí official active in the 580ies) said:
“How could the your Way, our Master
be less than this?”
The Master said:
“Have you never thrice recited the (piece about the) Báiguī?
Heaven and Earth have given me birth,
but they could not rear me;
my father and mother reared me,
but they could not make me what I am.
The one who made me what I am was our Master (Confucius).
The Way is not only a matter of Heaven and Earth and parents,
it has a direct link to our Master
from whom it derives unbounded generous blessings.
Are you going to destroy the ‘tradition of moral decency’?”
(Wáng) Xiàoyì bowed twice and thanked him (Wáng Tōng)
and for the rest of his life he did not presume to approve or disapprove (of the sayings of Confucius, accepting them uncritically).
Wéi Dǐng 韋鼎 (died ca. 593, Suí dynasty official, censor, formerly serving the Chén 陳 dynasty) asked for an interview.
The Master saw him three times but three times did not enter into any conversation.
just making a show of polite deference, as if not up to the task.
When Wéi Dǐng left he told the disciples:
“If our Master ever realised his aspirations at any court
it will be through moral education without words
and through strictness without killing.”
Yáng Sù 楊素 (died 606, poet and general, also known as “Sir” Yuè 越公, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors) said to the Master:
The Son of Heaven is looking for someone who is good at defending the border areas.
Now I have heard it said that only those of talent understand talent,
so I venture to ask you, our Master, about the matter.”
The Master said:
Yáng Hù 羊祜 (221-278, successful Jìn dynasty officer) and Lù Xùn 陸遜 (183-245, successful official of Wú 吳),
these were human-hearted men.
They may be employed.”
Yáng Sù said:
“But these people are dead already, aren’t they!
How can one still employ them?”
The Master said:
Now if you are capable of what Yáng and Lù were capable of, then you are fine;
but if you incapable of that
then looking for someone far and wide, what use is that?
I’ve heard it said:
‘When those close to one are pleased
and those far away will flock to one.’
then turning away attackers and laying on liquor for diplomatic guests is all you have to do.
Why go all the way to the border regions?”
In the home of the Master
the six classics were all on hand.
Formal court dress and sacrificial tools were never borrowed.
He (Wáng Tōng) said:
“The Three Rules and the Five Moral Constants
can be developed from these (books and utensils).”
The Master said:
“Those innumerable parasites (who eat without working)
they are Everywhere Under Heaven.
Through whom, then, shall the Way of the Kings come to thrive?”
The Master said:
“Under the seven rulers practicing administrative principles
their people could be used in the military.”
When Dǒng Cháng died
the Master lamented outside his bedroom
bowed and received condolences.
Péi Xī 裴晞 (fl. around AD 618, WT’s uncle-in-law, mentioned in Zīzhìtōngjiàn 資治通鑑 for an appointment in AD 618) asked:
“When Wèi Jiè 衛玠 (AD 286 - 312, Jìn dynasty official admired for his male beauty) judged others to have shortcomings
he was capable of showing forgiveness based on facts;
when they by no means had acted deliberately towards others
he was able to find reason to forgive them.????
How about that sort of behaviour?”
The Master said:
“It is certainly broad-minded!”
Péi Xī asked:
“But is he kind-hearted?”
The Master said:
“I cannot tell.”
“Ruǎn Jí 阮籍 (AD 210 - 263, very famous lyrical poet), when he talked to people,
reached profound far-reaching topics,
and he never passed judgment, positive or negative, on others.
How about that kind of behaviour?”
The master said:
“He was certainly circumspect!”
Péi Xī asked:
“But is he human-hearted?”
The Master said:
“I cannot tell.”
The Master said:
“Even-minded indeed was Líng Jìng (dates unknown, recorded as an official in late Suí/early Táng times)!
He treated other people’s orphans like his own.” (己 npro(.adN))
The Master said:
“If, as for the human-hearted,
I cannot get to find any,
then if I can (at least) see a wise person (which is the next best only)
that will do;
If, as for the wise persons,
I cannot get to find any
then if I can a just-minded person
that will do.
If I cannot find such a person
then what is needed is a strong and a resilient person!
A strong person is prone to be decisive,
and a assertive people will diverge from the run-of-the-mill.”
Xuē Shōu asked about ultimate virtue and the main Way.
The Master said:
“Ultimate virtue,
that surely is the basis of the Way!
The main Way,
that surely is the enacting of virtue!
Does not the Rituals have it
that ‘Ultimate virtue is the basis of the Way,’
and does not the Book of Changes speak of:
‘when one glorifies the way spiritual virtue will be practised’?
The Master said:
“Great indeed is the spiritus motor.
It is that from which things proceed.
Perfect indeed are the Changes.
Surely the book was produced by someone who understood that spiritus motor.
The Master said:
“I have never seen anyone who was as fond of what is right as he was of what is profitable to him.”
The Master ascended the Mid-Cloud Wall
and he looked into the distance towards Lóngmén Pass.
He said:
“Truly sturdy, these defences of mountains and rivers!”
Jiǎ Qióng said:
“Given that they are so sturdy
what more does one have to add?”
The Master said:
“One must safeguard these in accordance with the Way.”
He descended and stayed at the temple to Emperor Yǔ,
where he observed an inscription at the top of a stele:
“This has been produced by the deceased “Sir”??? Xiàn (my grandfather 安康獻公),
The text has classical dignity and puts across the message.”
The Master saw the Treatise on Cutting off Relations by Liú Xiàobiāo 劉孝標 (462-521, famous man of letters and commentator on Shìshuōxīnyǔ 世說新語)
and he said:
It is a great pity
that he commends Rèn Fāng 任昉 (AD 460-508, famous prose writer and bibliophile) and then goes on to criticise him (when he sees how his children turn out)..
Henceforth Rèn Fāng cannot be said to have understood personalities (failing to bring up his sons properly…???).”
He (WT) saw the Treatise on Disquisitions on Fate
and he said:
“That is the end of the Way of Man!” *******I am still struggling to get the subtlety of this 11.42…*****?????
The Master said:
“If Zhūgé Liàng (AD 181 - 234, legendarily skillful loyal minister of Shǔ 蜀 in the Romance of the Three Kingdoms) had not died,
ritual propriety and ritual music would have surely got to thrive!”
When the Master was reading the Treatise on Yuè Yì,
he commented:
“How human-hearted Yuè Yì 樂毅 (general in Yān in late Warring States times, precise dates uncertain) was!
And he was good at hiding his useful points.
How clever Xià Hóuxuán 夏侯玄 (209 - 254 BC, distinguished man of letters (and beau garçon), official and general under the Wèi 魏) was!
And he was good at bringing out his potential.”
The master read the Treatise on the Non-Existence of Ghosts
and he said:
“He (Ruǎn Zhān 阮瞻) never understands man,
how is he to understand ghosts?”
The Master said:
“The wise are joyful:
that is surely because he is mindful of the of what things will tend to do!
The human-hearted are long-lived:
that is surely because they disregard their own selves will tend to do!”
The Master said: The Master said
(Yáo) Yì 姚義 (dates uncertain, prominent young disciple, one of the presumed compilers of the Zhōngshuō 中說) is pure and vigorous;
(Lǐ) Qīng (571-649) is generous and incisive;
(Dòu) Wēi (died 618) is harmonious and broad;
(Xuē) Shōu (592-614) is resilient and serious;
(Jiǎ) Qióng (prominent disciple, dates unclear) is clear-sighted and firm;
(Dù) Yǎn (died 628) is earnest and severe;
(Fāng) Xuánlíng (579-648) is determined and discreet;
(Wèi) Zhēng (580－643, famous intellectual and Taoist monk, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors) is straightforward and efficient;
(Wēn) Dàyǎ (dates unknown, Suí dynasty official, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors) is profound an far-reaching;
(Chén) Shūdá (died 635) is plain and straight.
If these meet the right times
they will become nothing less and senior ministers or prime ministers,
and yet, as for ritual propriety and ritual music then these they are not fully capable of.”
Someone said:
“What kind of a person is Dǒng Cháng?
The Master said:
“When he takes the initiative he is responsive to the times,
when he remains inactive he reaches perfection.
He surely is of the type of Yán Huí 顏回 (ca. 521 - 481 BC, Confucius’s unambitious favourite disciple who died young)!”
Wáng Níng said:
“Shān Tāo 山濤 (205-283, one of the famous seven sages of the bamboo grove) was a human resources official
and he picked out men of talent and promoted the excellent,
but in his times no one understood what he was doing.
After his death
the Son of Heaven issued his memorials to the court
and only then one understood that all the talents were people whom Shān Tào had put forward.
What (do you think) about that?”
The Master said:
“He was discreet!”
Wáng Níng continued:
“But was he human-hearted?”
The Master said:
“That I cannot tell.”
Lǐ Mì 李密 (582-618, a military man and a famous strategist) visited the Master and discussed military affairs.
The Master said:
“As for ritual propriety and good faith, human-heartedness and justice
these things I will discuss;
treacherousness and pretence, deceit and power play,
these are things I will have nothing to do with.”
Lǐ Bóyào 李伯藥 (565-648, poet and successful official) visited the Master and discussed lyrical poetry.
The Master gave no response.
Lǐ Bóyào told (Wáng Tōng’s disciple) Xuē Shōu:
“Regarding the past I held forth on Yīng Jū 應琚 (190—252, learned writer)) and Liú Zhēn 劉楨 (died ca. AD 217, one of the legendary Seven Sages of the Bamboo Grove)
and regarding more recent times I transmit the teachings of Shěn Yuē 沈約 (441 - 513, learned poet and philologist) and Xiè Língyùn 謝靈運 (385 - 433, famous landscape poet);
I separated the four tones and the Eight Mistakes(cacophonies?)
the hard and the soft, the pure and the muddy (in phonology).
They were all in their proper order
the sounds were (well-tuned) like those of the xūn and the chí flutes.
but the Master never made any reply to me.
Could it be that the Master hasn’t yet quite got a grasp of these things?”
Xuē Shōu said:
“I have once heard our Master discuss lyrical poetry:
Above they make clear the Three Guidelines,
below they make one understand the Five Principles.
It is then that one finds evidence for survival and ruin,
and one analyses properly success and failure.
Thus the petty man chants them in order to pay homage to his (vulgar) customs,
the superior man chants them in order to show up his aspirations,
and the sage selects them in order to survey the historical variations.’
Now you are busy racing about in the lower reaches,
and this is what irks our Master.
His refusal to react has its reason!”
The Master said:*
As for study,
is it all about reciting things on a large scale?
What is necessary is linking things systematically to the Way!
As for dignified pattern,
is it all about producing things at will?
What is necessary is getting through to what is right!”
Secretary of the Interior Xuē Dàohéng 薛道衡 (540-609, friend of Lǐ Délín 李德林, Suí dynasty official who died AD 591) visited the Master in Cháng’ān.
When he withdrew Xuē Dàohéng said to (his son, WT’s prominent disciple) Xuē Shōu:
“The River Picture and the Luò Writing
they are all there in such a man.
You go ahead and serve him,
you should never miss this opportunity!”
The Master said:
“For a scholar who wears fine clothes with holes and eats rare dishes, for him then to take delight in the Way,
that I have yet to see!”
The Master said to Wèi Zhēng 魏徵 (580－643, famous intellectual and Taoist monk):
“You and (my brother Wáng) Níng are both the straightest people in the world.
Zhēng is efficient;
Níng is upright.
If they both have to act on a given occasion
one of them will be employed, the other rejected.
The Master said to Lǐ Jìng 李靖 (AD 571 - 649, official, probably never Wáng Tōng’s disciple, but held an appointment not far from WT’s place):
“If (my brother Wáng) Níng is given a chance in these times
then the laws of the Kings will prevail undistorted.”
Lǐ Jìng (AD 571 - 649, official, probably never Wáng Tōng’s disciple, but held an appointment not far from WT’s place) asked:
“How about relying on wisdom?”
The Master replied:
“Human-heartedness one regards as one’s own burden LY 8.7).
The petty man relies on wisdom and goes against human-heartedness and ends up a thief;
when the gentleman (NOT: superior man) relies on wisdom and goes against human-heartedness he starts a revolt.”
Xuē Shōu asked what kind of a person Zhòngzhǎng Zǐguāng 仲長子光 (date unknown, famous recluse and friend of Wáng Tōng as well as of his famous younger brother, the poet Wáng Jì 王績) was.
The Master said:
“He is a man (with a vision) from Heaven.”
Xuē Shōu said:
“What is a ‘man from Heaven’?”
The Master said:
“He is completely insignificant in appearance!
That is why he ranks below others.
But he has a broad grand vision!
And alone he can realise this his own ‘Heaven’.”
Jiǎ Qióng asked about the Way of a superior man.
The Master said:
“He must, before all else, have empathy!”
Jiǎ Qióng asked:
“May I ask for an explanation of empathy?”
The Master said:
“As somebody’s son
one must make one’s father’s attitudes one’s own attitudes;
as a younger brother
one must make one’s eldest brother’s attitudes one’s own attitudes.
When one generalises this to reach out to All Under Heaven,
then that is it.”
The Master said:
“The superior man, through study, progresses towards the Way;
the petty man, through study, progresses towards profit.”
When troubles arose in Chǔ (AD 613, unsuccessful revolt by Yáng Xuángǎn 楊玄感 (died AD 613))
they sent an envoy to summon the Master,
but the Master did not go.
He told the envoy:

“Offer my apologies to Yáng Xuángǎn 楊玄感 (died AD 613, revolted against the Suí dynasty, son of Yáng Sù 楊素 (died 606, poet and general, also known as Duke of Yuè 越公, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors)).
The ruler’s death and the political disorder in All Under Heaven
cannot, in truth, be settled by others than those of royal or ducal blood.
If something is not really the right thing to do
then one should never plant the seeds of disaster (by doing it).”
Lǐ Mì 李密 (582-618, a military man and a famous strategist) asked about a general strategy for kings and hegemons.
The Master said:
“Do not sacrifice a single ordinary person’s life for the sake of (gaining control over) All Under Heaven!”
When Lǐ Mì had left
the Master said to Jiǎ Qióng:
“This fellow is the one who is bound to ruin All Under Heaven.
Those who rejoice in the misfortune (of others) and yearn for (other people’s) disaster
those who love power and have ambitions for victory,
the spirits will not side with them.”
When the Master staid at home
even to the little boys and girls he was sure to show informal concern;
when he was giving his orders to others,
then even towards servant boys he was sure to maintain a formal countenance (as if they were senior aides).
The Master said:
“I have never seen anyone who understood decreed fate.”
The Master said:
“Not to go for profit,
not to avoid harm;
not to have artificial good relations,
not to break off relations arbitrarily,
only someone who is possessed of the Way is capable of these things.”
When the Master personally tilled the fields.
Someone asked him:
“Surely that’s hard work!”
The Master said:
“If one ordinary chap does not till the fields
others will suffer the resulting famine:
and this is the official job of any ordinary person.
If one fails in one’s duty,
this is a crime from which one escape to nowhere between Heaven and Earth.
Can I escape?”
The Master cultivated broomcorn millet and moved it to the threshing ground.
In the course of one year he harvested no more than some dàn worth.
This was used to supply for the sacrifices, the adulthood ceremonies, the weddings and for the alcohol served to visitors.
When the requirements for ritual were fulfilled he stopped (the work).
(However) in the Master’s house
there never was a shortage of alcohol.
Xuē Fāngshì (possibly same as 薛知仁 below) asked about funerals.
The Master said:
“For the poor one wraps up their limbs;
for the rich one provides outer and inner coffins.
The rules for the burial site was that it must never be large,
and it must not occupy good agricultural land.
The ancients did not harm the living or the sake of the dead.
and they would not make opulence a ritual requirement.”

Chén Shūdá 陳叔達 (573- 635 poet, 16th or 17th son of Emperor Xuān of Chén 陳宣帝(530 - 582), apparently part of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors) asked about the Way of serving the ghosts and the spirits.
The Master said:
“Show them respect and keep them at a distance!” LY
He asked about the jì sacrifice.
The Master said:
“How should there be a question of jì only?
There is also the sì sacrifice.
There is the jì sacrifice,
and there is the hosting.
The three are not the same.
These are the mysteries by which the former sages were in contact with the Three Powers (Heaven/Earth/Man).
When one has grasped the explanation of those three
then there is nothing that one does not attain to.”
(Chén) Shūdá bowed his head.
The Master said:
“Wáng Měng 王猛 (325 - 375, famous politician and general) had three virtues of a superior man:
In serving those above he was discreet;
in contacts with those below he was warm-hearted,
in dealing with official tasks he was decisive.”
Someone asked about Sū Chuò 蘇綽 (498-546, famous martial arts personality).
The Master said:
“He is a heroic man.”
The other man continued:
“What is his Way like?”
The Master said:
“When acting in times of warring states he can be strong;
in times of peace he will create political revolts.”
He asked about Niú Hóng 牛弘 (545-610, famous official and general).
The Master said:
“He is (simply) a magnanimous person.”
The Master was surveying the fields.
Wèi Zhēng 魏徵 (580－643, famous intellectual and Taoist monk), Dù Yǎn 杜淹 (died 628, famous man of letters and recluse on Tàishān) and Dǒng Cháng 董常 (favourite disciple) arrived on the scene.
The Master said:
“Let each of you speak of their aspirations.” LY
(Wèi) Zhēng said:
“I hope to serve an enlightened king,
to offer my reflections and to do my very best in his service.
When retiring from the service to reflect and to make up for my mistakes.”
(Dù) Yǎn said:
“I hope to be in charge of the laws of an enlightened king,
and to see to it that there will be no innocent victims of injustice.”
(Dǒng) Cháng said:
“I hope that the Way of the sage will be practised in our times
and that as for me I don’t have to worry about employment or retirement.”
The Master said:
“Superb! I side with Cháng.”
When the Master was in Cháng’ān,
he said:
“Let’s go home!
Today’s people who are so fond of the strange and make their frivolous progress
arise in waves.
There is nothing to choose between them!”
When the Master was in Jiàng
a certain Chéng Yuán 程元 (dates unknown, one of Wáng Tōng’s four main disciples) came to visit, introduced by Xuē Shōu.
The Master talked to him about the Six Classics
When (Chéng) Yuán withdrew he told (Xuē) Shōu:
“Our Master transmits and creates the Great Moral Truth.
He unifies the ultimate principles.
But for our Master
I would surely have lost my way in misguided views.”
The Master said:
“Presumably there are those who create because they crave fame,
but I do nothing of the kind!”
Wáng Níng said:
“The period when Wén Zhōngzǐ’s teaching flourished
was surely during the declining years of the Suí,
when the royal house (of the Táng) had not yet established itself!
As for the party who was about to go under
it hurts me to think that he did not get used;
as for the party who was about to rise
I regret that he did not get an audience them.
His aspirations were persistent,
his pronouncements were well-argued.
Surely, the ambition he set for himself was to serve the common people!”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“The two emperors (Yáo and Shùn) and the three kings (emperor Yǔ, Tāng the Great of the Shāng and King Wén of Zhōu),
I have not been able to meet/see them.
Apart from the two Hàn dynasties, where is one to go (to find people of such caliber)?
Great indeed was the ruler who established the Seven Systems (in Hàn times).
Surely they governed All Under Heaven using human-heartedness, justice, public spirit and fairness!
The corvée labour they demanded was simple,
the punishments they imposed were clear.
The superior man will delight in their Way,
the petty man will profit in their lives from them.
Four hundred years
there were no ambiguous aspirations in All Under Heaven (they all being in harmony with those of the emperors of the Hàn).
That surely was because they had something by which to align together the attitudes of the population.
To bring this to a successful conclusion with ritual propriety and with ritual music,
that was the great deed of the three kings.
The Master said:
“When the Way of the kings has been all mixed up for a long time,
can one fail to go about straightening out ritual propriety and ritual music?
When great justice is overgrown by brambles to this extent,
can one fail to write Sequels to the Songs and to the Documents?”
The Master said:
“The Way of Yáo and Shùn was straight and grandiose,
and so they finished by yielding the throne.
What was necessary was for there to be a sage to continue the tradition.
But why should it be necessary to fix laws?
The Way is very broad,
one cannot spell it out for posterity.
The Way of the Xià and of the Shāng was straight and simple,
so they finished up by setting loose assassins (last emperors Jié and Zhòu of Xià and Shāng dynasties respectively).
What was necessary then was for a sage to support them.
But why should this have to devolve on me?
Surely the Way is broad (leaves open many possibilities),
and it cannot be controlled from below (or: for lower generations).
If there is someone who will employ me
I shall surely be able to achieve what the Duke of Zhōu achieved!”
The Master was living at his ease
with Dǒng Cháng and Dòu Wēi (died 618, important early Táng politician) in attendance.
The Master said:
“In find that, more than a thousand years ago
when there was a sage in charge,
there was no one who lived up to the standards of the Duke of Zhōu.
The Duke of Zhōu’s way was unified
and the standard administrative systems were very much in place.
So later administrators
had something keep to and to follow.
I find that, less than one thousand years ago,
there was no one who lived up to the standards of Confucius.
Confucius’s way was unified
and his transmission was greatly enlightening.
So later writers of literature
had an ideal to aim for.
Over the last one thousand years
if there were any who properly expounded the facts around the Duke of Zhōu,
I have not got to notice them.
Over the last one thousand years
if there were those who introduced and promoted the main concerns of Confucius,
I have been unable to yield precedence to them.
“Quite possibly, Dǒng Cháng must have been something of a mystic.
Remaining at rest and proving no points, he still is worth employing.
And when he reflects, on occasion, he has a stroke of genius.”
Lǐ Jìng (AD 571 - 649, official, probably never Wáng Tōng’s disciple, but held an appointment not far from WT’s place) asked about the Way of the Sage.
The Master said:
“Well, if there is nothing that you follow,
you will surely not reach that level (of the Sage).”
A follower said:
“But (Wèi) Zhēng 魏徵 (580－643, famous intellectual and Taoist monk, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors) reached this level!”
Someone else said:
“Not quite!”
The entourage didn’t know what to think of this.
The Master said:
“(Wèi) Zhēng has left this mundane level,
but he has not reached that level.”
Someone asked for an explanation of ‘that level’.
The Master said:
“That level
Dǒng Cháng said:
“Our Master’s Way,
it emerges with things (i.e. on concrete occasions),
and it disappears with things (i.e. on concrete occasions).
In emerging there is nothing it follows,
in disappearing there is nothing it takes his cue from.”
Xuē Shōu said:
“Great is our Master’s Way.
There is one such, that is all.”
The Master said to Chéng Yuán 程元 (dates unknown, one of Wáng Tōng’s four main disciples):
“How do you relate to Dǒng Cháng?
Chéng Yuán said:
“I dare not aim for the level of (Dǒng) Cháng.
(Dǒng) Cháng has left behind>gone beyond the Way and Virtue.
My own aspiration (still) is human-heartedness and justice.”
The Master said:
“(Dǒng) Cháng is the one who has it right!
and you, in your concern with human-heartedness and justice,
you are not even quite at the level (in the Zhuāngzǐ 莊子) of being a mere busy-body.
He (Dǒng Cháng) has surely got somewhere in relation to that (superior) level of things.” See 2.37
The Master said:
Dǒng Cháng does reflect (abstractly) on things from time to time.
As for the rest he only thinks through action and inaction.”
The Maser said:
“How filial Xuē Shōu is!
In his actions he does not offend against the dead or the living.”
On a day when the Master paid condolence or engaged in the jì sacrifice
he would not smile all that day long.
Someone asked about Wáng Yǐn 王隱 (DATES!!!!!!!!author of the Jìn shū 晉書 “History of the Jìn”).
The Master said:
“He is an intelligent person.
His natural endowments are clear,
his talents are rich,
his learning is sufficient.”
Someone asked about his Way.
The Master said:
“His works are many but his guiding system of thought is shallow;
The subject of his Way is not worth bringing up.”
The Master said that Chén Shòu 陳壽 (233-297, famous compiler of the Sānguózhì 三國志 “History of the Three Kingdoms”) had set his mind on historiography,
and that he relied on the main meaning, cutting out the alternative approaches.
He said that Fàn Níng 範寧 (339-401, famous scholar-official some of whose commentaries survive) had set his mind on the Annals,
and that he adduced the sage’s classic and investigated the various traditions regarding it.
The Master said:
“If Chén Shòu was not admired in historiography,
that was the fault of Sīmǎ Qiān and of Bān Gù (who were so clearly his superior).
And if Fàn Níng (339-401) was not completely unreservedly admired with regard to the Annals
that is the fault of (Liú) Xīn 劉歆 (50 BC - 20 BC, very famous bibliographer, editor, and philologist) and of (Liú) Xiàng 劉向 (77 BC - 6 BC, very famous bibliographer, editor, and philologist).”
Péi Xī 裴晞 (WT’s uncle-in-law, mentioned in Zīzhìtōngjiàn 資治通鑑 for an appointment in AD 618) said:
“What does that mean?”
The Master said:
“The failure of historiography
begins after Sīmǎ Qiān and Bān Gù,
because one recorded details and had little of an overall message.
The failure regarding the Annals
begins after Liú Xīn and Liú Xiàng.
One rejected>forgot about the classic and relied on the traditions/commentaries.”
The Master said:
“It seems that when the Nine Masters (??) rose, the Way of the Changes dissolved into subtle quibbling,
When the three Commentaries were made, then the Annals disintegrated.”
Jiǎ Qióng asked:
“What do you mean?”
The Master said:
“When disapproval and approval change into each other
can there be other than decline?
when agreement and disagreement interfere with each other
can there be other than disintegration?
Thus the Qí, Hán Máo and Zhèng (schools of interpretation of the Songs)
are epigones of the Songs.
The Elder Dài and the Younger Dài
represent the decline of the Rituals.
The Documents are ruined by the Old Texts and the New Texts,
the Songs are lost in the Qí and Lǔ traditions.
You see the point?”
(The disciple) Jiǎ Qióng said:
“In that case: is it all right to be without teachers and without traditions/commentaries?”
The Master said:
“To understand things in a spiritual manner,
that depends on the right person;
if it isn’t the right person,
the Way does not get put into practice just like that.
What is necessary is a transmission,
and it must not be given up.”
The Master said to (his brother) Wáng Níng:
“You have not worked on the Sequel to the Songs?
Then your view of the regress and progress of the seven dynasties
will ultimately remain obfuscated.”
The Master said:
“With the Sequel to the Songs one can satirise
one can get to the bottom of things,
one can indulge oneself,
one can take one’s own stand;
when outside one will show brotherly respect,
when at home one will show filial piety;
and at many points one will notice the essence of good government and chaos.”
“As for my “teacher”,
it is this: ‘words must make their point, that is all.”

Someone asked about Yáng Xióng (53 BC to AD 18, very famous poet and man of letters, author of Fǎyán 法言, a work which like the Zhōngshuō 中說, is written very much in the style of the Analects) and Zhāng Héng 張衡 (AD 78-139, famous poet and scientist).
The Master said:
“These were truly remarkable men of antiquity:
their reflexions were bitter,
their pronouncements were difficult.”
The questioner continued:
“What was their Way like?”
The Master said:
“To remain serene!”
The Master said:
“Having made a mistake not to make it look dignified,
having been offended not to take lasting offence,
having merit not to show off with it,
that is to be a person of the superior man type.”
The Master said:
“I have never seen anyone who was pleased when being maligned,
or was afraid when being praised.”
The Master said:
“When someone is rich, observe those he associates with;
when someone is poor, observe what choices he makes;
when someone is a success, observe what preferences he has,
when someone is in straights, observe what he works for:
That will be fine.”
Someone asked about Emperor Xiàowén of Wèi 魏孝文 (reigned 467-499).
The Master said:
“With him one could make things thrive and transform things.”
Since the lady of Tóngchuān (lady Péi 裴, Wáng Tōng’s wife) was interested in medicines
the master started transmitting medical recipes;
since the lord of Ruìchéngfǔ (Wáng Tōng’s eldest brother) gave great importance to Yin and Yang
the Master started to write about the calendar.
Moreover, he said:
“I am afraid that those who look at these things may waste their time.”
The Master considered that Xuē Zhīrén (perhaps same as 薛方士 in 2.24) was good at dealing with local customs
and he gave him (his eldest brother) Ruìchéng’s (i.e.王度, sometime governor of Ruìchéng) daughter as a wife.
The Master said:
“When there are problems at home then to be able to straighten out one’s own intentions,
that was the method of the lord of Tóngzhōu Mansion (WT’s great-grandfather Wáng Yán 王彥).”
The Master said:
“When it comes to my relation to All Under Heaven (this world)
I neither walk away from it
nor do I have to engage with it.
What I follow is only the Way.”
Somebody asked about Yáng Sù 楊素 (died 606, poet and general).
The Master said:
“He has created good fortune for himself, he has created a position of authority, and he lives extremely well:
of the rest I know nothing.”
Fāng Xuánlíng (579 - 648, very famous politician and historian) asked about the political system of the provinces and districts.
The Master said:
“The various states under the ancestral Zhōu lasted for eight hundred years.
The Imperial Hàn made its mixed arrangements for more than four hundred years.
From the Wèi and the Jìn downwards
their demise came in no time.
I’m not so sure what the use of that system of provinces and districts is...”
Yáng Sù 楊素 (died 606, poet and general) sent someone to tell the Master:
“Why don’t you take official employment?”
The Master said:
“South of Shūshǔ
at the bend of the River Fèn,
the humble cottage of my forefathers is still there.
There one can shelter from wind and rain
and there are fields from which one can supply thick gruel.
Playing the lute and writing books,
expounding the way and encouraging justice one can take one’s pleasure.
I do hope that the rulers and lords straighten out their persons to govern coherently All Under Heaven.
When the seasons are good and the years are rich
then I for my part, old Tōng, receive many gifts!
My hopes are not for taking office.”
The Master said:
“Those who practised government in ancient times
put generous virtue first and punishments last,
and so their people were pleased and fair-minded;
those who practise government today
use punishments and leave generous virtue aside.
and so their people became resentful and deceitful.
The Master said:
“Those who in ancient times exercised office did so to feed others;
those who today exercise office feed themselves.”
The Master expostulated:
“Extreme indeed was the cruelty of Wén Xuān of the Northern Qí 北齊文宣王(Gāo Yáng 高洋, lived 529 - 559, died a violent death after ten years’ rule)!
Yáo Yì 姚義 (dates uncertain, prominent young disciple, one of the presumed compilers of the Zhōngshuō 中說) said:
“Why, then, do we say that he ‘managed to live to die a natural death’?”
The Master said:
“There was Yáng Zūnyàn 楊遵彥(minister to Wén Xuān of Qí)
and he was the one who, in the state, gave the orders.
He felt the (suffering of the) people as if he were suffering injury himself.
How should Wén Xuān not live to die a natural death?”
Dòu Wēi (died 618, important ambitious Suí politician) was fond of publicly discussing ritual propriety.
The Master said:
“Dòu Wēi is a man of talent.
I, for my part, have not the courage (to publicly discuss this).”
The North Mountain Fellow said to Wén Zhōngzǐ (i.e. Wáng Tōng):
“Why do they call you all panicked?
Are you without overeagerness?”
The Master said:
“I would not presume to be overeager.
What hurts me is the indifferent laziness of our times.”
The Master said:
“What I have not pondered carefully I do not maintain;
what is not according to a general rule I do not perform.”
Fāng Xuánlíng 房玄齡 (579 - 648, very famous politician and historian) said:
“In the Documents it says that Huò Guāng (ca.130 - 68 BC, powerful politician) dismissed emperors and raised emperors to office:
What do you have to say about that?”
The Master said:
“No need to mention Huò Guāng!
The senior ministers of ancient times
dismissed the obtuse and raised the enlightened
and that is how they brought peace to All Under Heaven.”
The Master travelled on the Islands in the Yellow River.
A Fellow From Above the Yellow River commented:
“What makes this man tick, one wonders!
He has a mind as if drunk on the Six Classics,
and he has a look as if wanting to sort out the Four Seas.
What makes this man tick, one wonders!”
Wén Zhōngzǐ (i.e. Wáng Tōng) left him.
Xuē Shōu asked:
“Who was that man?”
The Master said:
“He was a recluse.”
“Why don’t you become his follower?”
The Master said:
“The two of us have diverged ,/ for a long time!”
“But perfect men are in allegiance with each other!”
The Master said:
“(As you can see from this example:) Not so!”
The Master was on the banks of the Yellow River and said:
“How it gushes forth!
There was a time when I wanted to take a rest there,
but that turned out impossible.
Now, I have got here: I shall take a rest!”
The Master visited Governor Lǚyì (nothing is known about this person)
and he said:
“Yáo and Shùn examined achievements of officials after three years in office,
and Confucius would have achievements after three years.
Nowadays one changes staff every ten days, or every month.
I do not know what is going on.
Xuē Shōu said:
“Well, how does this come about?”
The Master said:
When the Three Dynasties flourished
nations had their altars of the land and grain;
when the Two Hàn Dynasties thrived
governorship was inherited down to sons and grandsons.
There was no such hurry, then!
If there is no stable ruler and one demands of people loyal effort,
if there is no stable people and one demands of it education,
then even if someone says he can do it,
he definitely does not have what it takes to get it done.”
Hè Ruòbì 賀若弼 (554 -647, ambitious politician renowned for his courage under the Suí dynasty) asked for archery instruction from the Master.
He hit the mark with every shot.
The Master said:
“What a splendid polite art!
But the superior man in antiquity aspired to the Way,
based himself on Virtue,
and relied on human-heartedness.
Only after that were the polite arts something to be indulged in.”
Hè Ruòbì withdrew, dissatisfied.
The Master told his entourage:
“Boastfulness and reckless wilfulness,
how difficult these are to avoid in today’s world!”
The Master said about Xún Yuè 荀悅 (148 - 209, famous historian, philosopher, and politician):
“Ah, the histories! The histories!”
He said about Lù Jī (261-303, poet, theoretician of Chinese literature):
“Ah, literature! Literature!
All these, in their thought, got more than half of the truth!”
The Master said:
“From the writings the actions of a person may be seen.
Xiè Língyùn 謝靈運 (385 - 433, very famous landscape poet) was a petty man.
His writings are arrogant,
the superior man, on the contrary, is diligent.
Shěn Yuè 沈約 (441～513, famous philologist and poet) was a petty man.
His writings are seductive
the superior man, on the contrary, has a classical dignity.
Bāo Zhāo (鮑昭 414-466, very famous but controversial poet) and Jiāng Yǎn 江淹 (444 - 505, poet official)
were what was the the irascible kind in ancient times.
Their writings were impatient and resentful.
Wú Jūn 吳均 (469-520, poet known for his old-fashioned style) and Kǒng Guī (447 - 501, poet official)
were what was the eccentric kind in ancient times:
their writings are strange and full of anger.
Xiè Zhuāng 謝莊 (421-466, poet official) and Wáng Róng 王融 (468-494, poet official)
were what was the subtle kind in ancient times.
Their writings are disjointed.
Xǔ Líng 徐陵 (507-583, poet official) and Yǔ Xìn 庾信 (513-581, very famously allusive and elusive obscurantist poet)
were what was the grandiloquent in ancient times.
Their writings were unrestrained.”
Someone asked about the brothers Liú Xiàochuò 劉孝綽 (581-639, poet official) and Liú Xiàowēi 劉孝威 496 - 549, poet official, 6th younger brother of Liú Xiàochuò).
The Master said:
“These are greedy men.
Their writings are expansive.
Xiè Tiào 謝朓 (441-531, poet official)
was a shallow man.
his writings are facile.
Jiāng Zòng (519-594, poet official)
was a deceitful man.
His writings are fictitious.
These were all unprofitable men of former times.
The Master said:
“Yán Yànzhī (384-456, famous scholar, poet, and official), Wáng Jiǎn (452-489, poet official), and Rèn Fāng (460-506, poet official)
have the attitudes of their superior man.
Their writings are concise and they are principled.”
The Imperial Comptroller summoned the Master to take office (in the central administration).
The Master sent (his disciple) Yáo Yì to go to decline the offer
saying:
“If it must be,
then deputise me to Shǔ (far-away Sìchuān).”
Someone objected:
“But that is an out-of-the-way place!”
The Master said:
“If I can follow Yán Jūnpíng 嚴君平 (86 BC - AD 10, Taoist scholar and commentator) and Yáng Xióng 揚雄 (53 BC - AD 18, very famous poet, playful writer, and intellectual),
why should I keep worrying about out-of-the-way-ness?”
The Master said:
“I do hate the glib-tongued!
If must be I prefer the dull-minded!
For the dull-minded do not take arbitrary action.
I do hate the spendthrifts!
If must be I prefer the niggard!
The niggard will not spend resources arbitrarily.”
The Master said:
“An accomplished person was Shān Tāo 山濤 (205-283, one of the legendary Seven Worthies of the Bamboo Grove)!
There was much that is acceptable in him, and little that he one would blame him for.
Someone said:
“Was Wáng Róng 王戎 (234 - 305, another member of the legendary Seven Worthies of the Bamboo Grove) talented?”
The Master said:
“If Wáng Róng counts as talented
then there are no non-talented people in All Under Heaven.”
The Master said:

“Cáo Zhì 曹植 (192－232, Cáo Cāo’s 曹操 favourite son who lost the struggle to succeed his father to his more ambitious elder brother Cáo Pī 曹丕, also an important man of letters and literary critic) may be considered to have fully understood the principles of things.
He yielded All Under Heaven to someone else.
But of the people of his time none understood him.”
The Master said:
“Truly superior was Cáo Zhì!
His writings were profound so as to have a classic dignity.”
Fāng Xuánlíng (579 - 648, very famous politician and himself a famous historian) asked about historiography.
The Master said:
“The historical works of former times were were critically eloquent about the Way (i.e. moral issues);
the historical works of our time try to be dazzling through literary excellence.
When asked about literary excellence
the Master said:
“Literary excellence of former times was to be concise so as to make one’s point;
literary elegance these days is multifarious so as to block up the issues.”
Xuē Shōu asked about the Sequel to the Songs.
The Master said:
“There are four key terms in it,
and there are five main aspirations in it.
What are these four terms?
The first is transformation:
it is the means whereby the Son of Heaven transmogrifies All Under Heaven.
The second is administration:
it is the means by which the various ministers aligned the customs;
The third is eulogy:
it reports achieved results to the Enlightened Spirits.
The fourth is sighs:
by laying out teachings it establishes admonitions for the family.
Of these altogether four things
some celebrate beauty in something,
some encourage towards something,
some express sadness about something,
some express dislike of something,
and some admonish towards something.
These are the five literary aspirations.
The Master told (his younger brother) Wáng Níng:
“Have you worked on the Annals and the Primal Classic?
The Annals and the Primal Classic in relation to the Way of the kings
are weighing scales,
they are ink-lines establishing what is crooked and what is straight.
If you fail to use these you have no way of choosing the proper means.”
The Master said:
“The huà (“educational point”) in the Sequel to the Songs
is surely like that of the yǎ (“classical dignity”) of the Former Kings!
The administrative thought in the Sequel to the Songs
is surely like the various states having their local Airs (fēng)?”
The Master said:
“The zhèng ‘administration’ in the case of the provinces and districts
they surely distinguish between the fēng ‘local Airs’ of the various states!
When the Airs of the various states are deep-rooted so as to be fixed in their ways,
and their people are firm.
They say:
‘Our ruler will not, in the end, make any demands on us.’
Surely superiors and inferiors will be at peace with each other!
When there is a political revolt
they will be troubled and will disperse.
Then the people will probably feel sad that the ruler’s benefits become slighter,
but they will not presume to resent him.
When the administration of provinces and districts gives satisfaction and brings good fortune (to the people)
then the people will fondly look up to (their ruler),
and they will say>think:
‘When our ruler does not, in the end, take good care of us,
then ministers and lords will change frequently.’
And when there is political revolt,
there will be cruelty and oppression
and the people will presumably resent the callousness of the magistrates’ attitudes.
and they have nothing to feel saddened sympathy with.?????
Then even if there is a good administration
there is to time to put it into effect.”
Wèi Zhēng (580－643, famous intellectual, politician, and Taoist monk) said:
“May I ask about this point that when there are variations in the Airs of the various states
the people feel saddened sympathy but no resentment
but when there are revolutions in the administration of provinces and districts
then there is resentment but no saddened sympathy.
What does that mean?”
The Master said:
“In the case of feeling saddened sympathy but no resentment
then they will say: ‘He still is our ruler.
How can we escape from him?’
How would they presume to resent him?
In the case of resenting and not feeling saddened sympathy
then they will say: ‘He is beyond the pale.
we must treat him as a thief.’
How would they go on to feel saddened sympathy for him?
Thus it is said: At the end of the Three Dynasties (Xià, Shāng, Zhōu)
there still subsists that human-heartedness and justice,
but during the declining years of the Six Dynasties
human-heartedness and justice are all gone!
So why is that?
It is because the guidance of others is not along the right path.”
The Master said:
“When the Biànfēng and the Biànyǎ were produced the ‘royal bounty’ was used up;
when the Biànhuà and the Biànzhèng (apparently chapters of Wáng Tōng’s Sequel to the Songs) were produced, the imperial system had declined.”
The Master said:
“To opt for something in speech and offend against it in action
this is what Wēn Yànbó 溫彥博 (564 -637, official, Wēn Dàyǎ’s 溫大雅 brother, member of Wáng Tōng group of visitors and interlocutors and presumably disciple) hated;
to praise someone to the face and the malign him behind his back
this is what Wèi Zhēng 魏徵 (580－643, famous intellectual and Taoist monk and member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors.) hated.”
The Master said
“Defeating human-heartedness in order to spare a life,
that is the conduct of a person of the lowest stupidity, isn’t it!
Sacrificing oneself in order to bring about human-heartedness
that the conduct of a middle quality person, isn’t it!
Among those who spent their time with Confucius
there was no one who failed to work at that middle quality.”
When Chén Shūdá (573- 635 poet, 16th or 17th son of 陳宣帝 (530 - 582)) became governor of the province of Jiàng,
he issued an order for the arrest of thieves in which it said:
“Never act rashly!
Someone who asks permission to become a new person, pardon him
and see how he develops afterwards.”
When the Master heard about this he said:
“With Governor Chén one can discuss administration!
The authorities have failed in the practice of the Way
and the people have lost their cohesion a long time ago.
If someone is not a superior man
how can he remain firm in poverty?
To guide people with virtue,
to try them out with trust,
and then to go on to observe the development,
is that not an excellent way to go about these things?”
Xuē Shōu asked:
“Generosity is not inconsistent with justice,
frugality is not incompatible with ritual propriety.
What is your comment on that statement?”
The Master said:
“This is what Emperors Wén 漢文帝 (202 - 157) and Jǐng 漢景帝 (188 - 141) of the Hàn dynasty were upset about it being so hard to put into practice.
Now the abandonment of mutilation punishments contravenes justice
but reducing them is acceptable;
wearing all rough black silk is inconsistent with ritual propriety
but a modicum of rough black silk is acceptable.
However this may be,
doing things in the spirit of Emperors Wén and Jǐng is acceptable.
But one must not take it as a fixed norm in these later times.”
The Master said:
“In ancient times one served a ruler in accordance with the Way,
and when that was impossible then one stopped;
nowadays they serve a ruler by sycophancy,
and there is nothing that is beyond them.”
The Master said:
“As for the Book of Changes Texts
I transmit them but I would not presume to discuss them;
as for ritual propriety and ritual music
I discuss them but would not presume to argue about them;
as for the Songs and the Documents
I argue about them, but I do not engage in public controversies about them.”
Someone asked for the reasons behind this.
The Master said:
“In some cases things are possible, in other cases they are not possible.”
The same person continued:“Are there things that are possible, and others that are not possible for you, our Master?”
The Master said:
“The possible and the not possible,
these are things that persist in All Under Heaven.
I am (a place) where these exist.”
When the Master lived at his ease he still maintained seriousness.
His movements were slow,
as if he was thinking about something;
his actions were methodical,
as if he was in fearful awe of something.
When receiving his seniors
he was all submissive, as if insufficient (as a host);
and when receiving his juniors
he was warm-hearted as if wanting to get close to someone.
The masters formal dress was frugal and neat,
and there were no (food) leftovers (old reading: zhàngwù).
fine silks of any sort
did not enter his house.
He said:
“The superior man will not wear anything but off white,
a woman, on the other hand, may have dark grey and emerald green.”
When formally receiving guests the Master never served two dishes,
in dishes he was sure to avoid what was fresh-uncooked
but the flavour was bound to be pleasing.
Fruits and vegetables he did not eat out of season,
saying
“(To eat things out of season) is not the Way of Heaven.”
Products from other regions he would not eat
saying:
“That is not the Way of Earth.”
There was a poor neighbour who was seeking to see him,
and he said:
“If you take things from me
as long as you do not disturb your neighbourhood and community
then I will have no objection.”
When the neighbour had a case of mourning
the master was bound to be the first to visit
and the last to leave (the funeral proceedings).
The Master’s words were (usually) responsive, and they did not take the initiative.
And if he did take an initiative, then it was to bring up a large issue.
None of the Master’s neighbours quarrelled with him.
If anyone asked him whether a person was excellent,
then if the Master knew he was excellent, he would praise him;
but if he was not good
then he would just mutter:“I have not known him for a long time.”
When the Master was about to cross a big river
if there was a storm, he would not go ahead.
He would not climb high mountains,
he would not step on craggy spots;
he would not steer a scared horse,
he would not drive fast.
When the neighbours had corvee labour of water works or earth works
then he would take along the round basket and the shovel.
He said
“I’m by no means beholden to any dignitary, am I!”
On the occasion of the funeral of the lord of Tóngchuān Mansion (Wáng Lōng 王隆 (no dates), Wáng Tōng’s father, much respected scholar, often referred to as the lord of the Tóngchuān Mansion.)
no spoon of food and no drink entered his mouth for three days.
When the preparations for the funeral were complete
(Wáng Tōng) said:
“One has to be frugal.
My family has a system in this regard.
The inner and outer coffins were without ornament,
They lifted him up dressed in a shroud,
they put him on curtained carriage,
the clay carriage and reed sacred figurines to go with him,
these had not been used for five generations.”
When they had buried him
(Wáng Tōng) said:
“From Confucius’ time onwards
there have always been commemorative sign.”
Then he established the tomb
which stood four foot tall.
He did not plant trees around.”
When the Master left his neighbourhood
then, when he was living with another family,
he was sure to let them know when he went out and when he was back.
In the end he said:
“How could I go anywhere without announcing this properly?”
On the occasion of the Myriad Spring Neighbourhood Altar of the Land Sacrifices
the Master was sure to join those responsible, all in natural respectfully dignified style.
The lord of the Ruìchéng Mansion (Wáng Dù 王度 (no dates available, Wáng Tōng’s elder brother who seems to have been part of the household of his younger brother) set up house as a censor
and when he was about to leave
he told Wén Zhōngzǐ:
“What is your parting gift for me?”
The Master said
“Be pure but not isolated,
be straight but not inflexible!”
Wáng Dù said:
“What do you have to add to this?”
The Master said:
“Make supreme harmony your outer appearance
and make utter earnestness your inner identity.
Carry these things out with polite humility
Safeguard these things according to the Way.”
Wáng Tōng’s brother left his brother’s company and told Dǒng Cháng:
“When a high building is about to collapse
it won’t be kept standing by a single beam.”
The Master said:
“In matters of marriage to talk about property
that is the Way of the Yí barbarians.
And a superior man will not enter their region.
In ancient times the clans of the man and the woman
each made their choice on considerations of virtue.
They did not consider property a matter of ritual propriety.”
In the Master’s clan
in any marriage the Six Wedding Rites had to be present.
He said:
“This proper practice
is nowadays in disuse.
The leading item of the Three Guidelines (regarding ruler/subject, father/son, husband/wife) are not to be abandoned.
I follow the ancients.”
The Master said:
“Poor dress and plain food,
few longings and few desires,
people nowadays consider their use deceptive,
but I, for my part, love to engage in this deceit.
Not to make an exaggerated scintillating show of things
looks like stupidity, resembles vulgarity,
people nowadays consider these as shameful
but I am not ashamed of these things.”
The Master said:
“The officials of ancient times,
they served in order to practise their Way;
the officials of our times
the serve in order to satisfy their desires.
It is a difficult situation!”
The Master said
“To be promoted to officialdom from menial service,
and to be appointed to high office for merit in service,
that is not the ancient practice.
Presumably it is a survival of Qín callousness!
In ancient times scholars rose to official position,
and menial officers kept to their menial services.
Apanages served to reward meritorious service,
and high offices were given to those possessed of virtue.
The Master said:
“Splendid was the way in which Duke Jī Dān of Zhōu 周公姬旦 (11th century BC, founding figure of the Zhōu dynasty) ran the state of Zhōu!
As far as outward appearances were concerned he did not condescend to pay attention to the slander of All Under Heaven and kept private the traces of his plans
saying:
I must ensure that my descendants will succeed each other
and that the ancestral sacrifices will be uninterrupted.
In his mind he fully understood the the Way of All Under Heaven and he made publicly known his mindset.
He said:
We must ensure that rulers and subjects be at peace with each other,
and that disasters as well as revolutions do not occur.
This is profound! This is profound!
By keeping peace at home one brings peaceful order to All Under Heaven;
by ensuring one’s own continued existence he is able to give rich benefits to all the creatures in the world.
Therefore the meaning of moving the capital went like this:
The territory around the city of Luòyáng
reaches out in all four directions, and brings peace,
Supposing there is virtue here the place will easily come to thrive;
supposing that there is no Virtue here, the place will easily decline.”
Wáng Jì 王績 (ca. 585 - 644, Wáng Tōng’s younger brother, famous unornate poet recluse writing in the tradition of Táo Yuānmíng 陶淵明) wrote the Record of Mr Wǔdǒu.
The Master commented:
“You are forgetting all about All Under Heaven, aren’t you.
You give free rein to your mind, and you ruin existing rules:
I will not be part of it!”
The Master said:
“As for the Way the sages were following
its flourishing is hidden away,
its decline is (like) a sleep (before a new flourishing).
Unceasing, like the cold and the warm seasons it moves forward and retracts.
All creatures follow along with it (in its flourishing and decline)
and they not understand its why and how.”
Wēn Yànbó (574-637, official, Wēn Dàyǎ’s 溫大雅 younger brother) asked:
What were Xī Kāng 嵇康 (223 - 262, very famous intellectual, poet, essayist and musician) and Ruǎn Jí 阮籍 (210 - 263, very famous lyrical poet, essayist and eccentric) like?”
The Master said:
“These are famous theoreticians of former times,
but they were unable to get to the bottom of things.”
Wēn Yánbó went on to ask:
“What do you mean?”
The Master said:
“Their Way was insufficient and their means of achieving it were excessive.”
Wēn Yánbó went on:
“May I ask about the Way and the means towards it?”
The Master said:
“Fully understanding the variations of things is called the Way.
Holding onto a certain method is called a means.”
Wēn Yànbó went on:
“What kind of a person was Liú Líng 劉伶 (ca. 221 - 300, poet notorious for his fondness of wine)?”
The Master said:
“A man who kept his door closed in ancient times.”
Wēn Yànbó went on:
“But was that acceptable?”
The Master said:
“Forgetting about each and everything in All Under Heaven
is that not perfectly all right?”
Wēn Yànbó went on:
“But is that Way sufficient?
The Master said:“Well, whether it is sufficient I am not so sure!”
Governor Chén (i.e. Chén Shūdá (573- 635 poet, 16th or 17th son of Emperor Xuān of Chén 陳宣帝(530 - 582)) ) told Xuē Shōu:
“I am implementing the orders in the province and in the districts and the thieves are not stopping their thievery.
But when our Master stays in a neighbourhood then all strife ceases.
Why is that?”
Xuē Shōu said:
“One man (Chén Shūdá) educates through his words
the other educates through his mind.”
Governor Chén said:
“Ah: then it is all my fault!”
He withdrew and lived at peace.
After three months the thieves and the thugs had left his territory.
When the Master heard about this, he said:
“Xuē Shōu is good at using words,
and Governor Chén is good at using Virtue.”
Fāng Xuánlíng (the disciple) asked:
“What kind of a man is Tián Chóu 田疇 (161 - 294, military man, appointed to office by Cáo Cāo 曹操, famously refused high rewards for his meritorious conduct)?
The Master said:
“A righteous man of former times.”
The Master said:
The Martial Virtue dance (of the first Hàn emperor) was exhausting but decisive,
it surely brought out the planning and moved reflection
to serve as a guideline to the Son of Heaven.”
The Displaying Virtue ritual dance (of the second Hàn emperor) was easy and majestic.
It surely brought harmony to the spirit and settled one’s vital energies
so as to keep calm All Under Heaven.”
The lord of the Tàiyuán Mansion (Wáng Níng 王凝 (no dates) often referred to as Shū Tián 叔恬, and as Tàiyuánfǔjūn 太原府君, Wáng Tōng’s younger brother, historian and official) said:
“What is all this about?”
The Master said:
“One (the Martial Virtue) was decisive so as to establish (the Hàn dynasty),
the other (the Displaying Virtue) was majestic so as to preserve (the dynasty).
I do not understand their variations.
Ah,
Through Martial Virtue
the success was assured.
But it is not as good as the excellence in Displaying Virtue.
Moreover, the Wǔ dance has not quite been perfect in a lasting way.
Surely (his achievement) was temporary!
The Master said,
“The historian (Sīmǎ) Tán was good at transmitting the Nine Currents (of Thought):
He understood what must not be rejected (in each);
but he also understood that each of them had their blemishes.
Where could he get the pronouncements of (such a) superior thinker (who is above all these schools of thought)?”
The Master said:
“When one understands the variations of things
there will be no faulty (unadjusted) laws in All Under Heaven;
when one holds onto one dogmatic recipe,
there is no excellent teaching in All Under Heaven.
Therefore it is said:
The crux is in (finding) the right person.”
The Master said:
“Where does one find a well-rounded scholar
with whom to discuss the Nine Currents (of Thought)?
Where does one find the ruler of the ultimate principles
with whom to sort out the Nine Over-arching Principles.”
Dù Yǎn 杜淹 (died 628, famous man of letters and recluse on Tàishān) asked:
“What kind of a man is Cuī Hào (？－450, leading Northern Wèi politician)?”
The Master said:
“He was a man under pressure.
He stuck to the small Way (i.e. the fāng 方)
and he messed up the Great Guidelines.”
Chéng Yuán said:
“May I ask about the Bīn Air?
The Master said:
“This is a varied Air.”
Chéng Yuán said:
“During the period of the Duke of Zhōu
were there then also Varied Airs?”
The Master said:
“When ruler and ministers ridicule each other
can that be a right state of affairs?
When in the end King Chéng of Zhōu (ca. 1042 - 1020) grew suspicious (of the Duke of Zhōu)
then the Airs did in the end get varied.
If the Duke of Zhōu 周公姬旦 (11th century BC, founding figure of the Zhōu dynasty) had not been perfectly earnest
who could have brought (the establishment of the Zhōu dynasty) to a successful end?”
Chéng Yuán said:
“The Bīn comes at the end of the Varied Airs.
Why is that?”
The Master said:
“From King Yí of Zhōu (reigned perhaps ca. 885—878) onwards
the Varied Airs never again became Straight Airs.
Our Master (Confucius) presumably felt bad about this,
therefore he finished the section off with the Airs of Bīn.
He maintained that as for the Varied Airs being able to be made Straight
only the Duke of Zhōu was capable of this.
So therefore he linked this section to the Straight section (of Elegancies)
and he praised the Bīn saying: ‘It is the basis of the Zhōu.’
Ah!
But for the Duke of Zhōu, who would have understood these difficulties?
For the varied he could put it straight,
for the precarious could prop it up ,
and to the end he did not to lose sight of what basic.
Surely only the Duke of Zhōu was capable of that.
Attaching (his songs) to the (Airs of) Bīn was indeed a far-sighted thing to do.”
The Master said:

When Huán of Qí (died 643 BC, leading feudal lord Earl Huán of Qí 齊桓侯, ubiquitously referred to in Western sources by the historical misnomer Duke Huán of Qí: he was a mere hóu 侯 “earl”, not a duke) brought honour to the Royal House (of Zhōu, ensuring unity of the empire by becoming a hegemon),
the feudal lords submitted.
Only Guǎn Zhòng (716 - 645, all-powerful prime minister under Earl Huán of Qí) understood what was going on.
When Fú Jiān 苻堅 (338-385, declared himself Dà Qín Tiānwáng 大秦天王 Heavenly King of the Great Qín, in the Former Qín dynasty) promulgated his (unlegitimised) great self-designation,
then the central plains were at peace.
Only Wáng Měng (325 - 375, senior minister under Fú Jiān 苻堅 (338-385)) understood what was going on.”
Someone objected:
“But Fú Jiān was disobedient!”
The Master said:
“This was the fault of those who organised the statutes of the state of Jìn.
There was no question of Fú Jiān being disobedient.
Formerly the Zhōu organised those perfectly public-spirited statutes,
so (Earl) Huán of Qí and Guǎn Zhòng did not get to break them;
the Jìn organised perfectly self-serving statutes
so Fú Jiān and Wáng Měng did not get to serve under them.
Did not they all respond to Heaven, follow the statutes, bring peace to the state and help the people?
Therefore King Wǔ of Zhōu (died ca. 1043) did not presume to disobey the decrees of Heaven or to turn his back on his fellow-human beings so as to serve (tyrant) Zhòu,
and (Earl) Huán of Qí did not presume to disobey the decrees of Heaven and to go against his fellow human beings so as to fail in his duties to the Zhōu.
That is why I maintain:
It was the fault of the state of Jìn,
and there is no question of Fú Jiān having been disobedient!
If for more than thirty years
the citizens of the central states
from east, west, south and north
covered large distances to come and show their allegiance,
that was because of Wáng Měng’s energetic contribution.”
The Master said
“Fú Jiān’s having a (proper) minister
was surely Wáng Měng’s doing!
The Northern Wèi’s having a (proper) ruler
was surely due to (its emperor) Xiàowén of Wèi 魏孝文帝 (reigned AD 467—499)!
The Way of the central states not declining,
was because of the strength of Xiàowén (of Wèi).
The lord of the Tàiyuán Mansion (Wáng Níng 王凝 (no dates, often referred to as Shū Tián 叔恬, and as Tàiyuánfǔjūn 太原府君, Wáng Tōng’s younger brother, historian and official) said:
“What kind of a man was Wēn Zǐshēng (died 547, poet official who connived with the emperor in the Yǒng’ān 永安affair mentioned below)?”
The Master said:
“He was the dangerous sort.
His wisdom was small, and his plans were large.
During the Yǒng’ān affair (AD 529, when emperor Zhuāng of Wèi 北魏莊帝 killed Ěr Zhūróng 爾朱容 whose family successfully counterattacked the emperor)
the lord of the Tóngzhōu Mansion (WT’s great grandfather Wáng Yàn 王彥) was constantly grinding his teeth (in anger at Wēn’s connivance with the emperor).
He had good cause!”
The Master was reading about his ancestors above the last three generations.
He said
“What dedication!
But they were of no help!
One must not think that there were no decent people in Wèi and Zhōu times!
It just so happens that my family was not employed.”
