As for the Master’s family temple
its position had to be facing south-east.
This tradition began with Duke Mù (of Jìnyáng) 晉陽穆公(Wáng Tōng’s ancestor Wáng Qiú 王虬 420 - 500, who fled to the Northern Wèi).
(The Masters) said:
“We have never ceased to be mindful of the state of our forefathers.”
As for the campaign of Liáodōng (AD 613 - 615, unsuccessful military campaign launched by Emperor Yáng of Suí 隋煬帝),
when the Master learned about it he said:
“Disaster will arise from this.
The Son of Heaven would not even look at Bó Yì’s 伯益 (also written 伯翳、伯蘩、柏翳、化益 legendary contemporary of the Emperor Yǔ) advice for Emperor Yǔ,
and the senior ministers did not use the method of Wèi Xiàng (died 59 BC, renowned advisor to Emperor Xuān of the Hàn 漢宣帝), going against Emperor Xuān (91 - 49 BC).”
Wáng Xiàoyì (Suí official active in the 580ies) said to the Master:
“Everyone in All Under Heaven is fighting over profit at the expense of rectitude/justice.
What on earth can one do?”
The Master said:
“Reject what they are fighting over
and opt for what they reject!
Is that not the ‘gentlemanly’ thing to do?”
The Master addressed Jiǎ Qióng, Wáng Xiàoyì and Líng Jìng 凌敬 (dates unknown, Suí-Táng official, apparently part of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors), saying:
“What do you people really enjoy?”
Jiǎ Qióng said:
“I enjoy living at my ease.”
The Master commented:
“Peacefully reflecting on the Way is a good thing to do!”
Wáng Xiàoyì said:
“I enjoy hearing about my mistakes.”
The Master commented:
“When one has made mistakes then to hear about them often
that does one good!”
Líng Jìng said:
“I enjoy meeting excellent people.”
The Master commented:
“Isn’t it a joy when there are many worthy people!”
Xuē Shōu was travelling in Guāntáo
and by coincidence he returned home together with Wèi Zhēng 魏徵 (580－643, famous intellectual and Taoist monk, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors).
He told the Master:
“Wèi Zhēng is the caliber of Yán Huí 顏回 (ca. 521 - 481, Confucius’s favourite disciple) and Rǎnyǒu 冉有 (ca. 522 - 489 BC, famous disciple of Confucius)。
When (Wèi) Zhēng staid in the Master’s home
he kept discussing the (Sequel to the) Six Classics,
and for more than a month he did not leave the house.
When he left,
he told Xuē Shōu:
When the enlightened kings were no longer forthcoming our Master (Wáng Tōng) was born,
and so all the profound truths about Heaven, Earth and Men came to belong (also) to us, the common people.”
Liú Xuàn 劉炫 (AD 546 -614, famous scholar) visited the Master
and they talked about the Six Classics.
He chanted the opening passages
tirelessly to the end of the day.
The Master said:
“Amazing, how many things there are.”
Liú Xuàn said:
“The ins and outs (divergences and convergences) of the former Rú
one cannot but transmit!”
The Master said:
“When one sorts out the underlying coherence of things, that is fine.
(But by the way:) do you think that Confucius was the sort who has learnt a lot and remembered it all?”
When Xuàn had left
the Master told his entourage:
“To make Confucius’s words into a display of rhetoric,
and to make his Way into a petty (professionalistic) achievement,
that is quite an ‘achievement’!”
Líng Jìng 凌敬 (dates unknown, Suí-Táng official, apparently part of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors) asked about the basis of ritual propriety and ritual music.
The Master said:
“Avoiding evil!”
When Líng Jìng had left
the Master said:
“A worthy man, this scholar!
he problematises ritual propriety and ritual music.”
“The Dàfēng Song is peaceful without disregarding danger.
Surely this is the embodiment of the spirit of leadership!
In the Qiūfēng Song, at the apogee of joy, grief supervenes.
Surely here are a sprouts of aspirations mindful of (possible) regret!
The Master said:
“As the Songs and the Documents thrived, the Zhōu 周(!) were destroyed,
but that was not the fault of Confucius.
When notions of emptiness and mystery dominated the house of Jìn was creating chaos,
but that was not the fault of Lǎozǐ and Zhuāngzǐ.
When (Buddhist) fasting and religious prohibitions were cultivated the state of Liáng was ruined,
but that was not the fault of the Buddha Shakyamuni.
Does not the Book of Changes say:
When there is not the right kind of person
the Way will not be practised just like that.” (Changes, 繫辭)
Someone asked about the Buddha.
The Master said:
“He was a sage.”
The questioner continued:
“What about his teaching?”
The Master said:
“It is a teaching from the West.
In the central states this will get bogged down.
With a formal sedan vehicle one cannot go to Yuè,
wearing a formal cap one cannot go to the Hú barbarians.
Such is the Way of the ancients.”
Someone asked about Yǔ Wénjiǎn 宇文儉 (died 578, scholar and general).
The Master said:
“He was a Rú of the superior-man type.
His sub-commentaries were pertinent, and his knowledge was far-reaching.
He surely had a deep understanding of the Documents!

The lord of the Tóngchuān Mansion (The reference is to Wáng Lōng 王隆 (no dates), Wáng Tōng’s father, much respected scholar, often referred to as the lord of the Tóngchuān Mansion) thought much of him,
and that definitely was not without reason!”
The Master was travelling in Tàiyuè,
and he heard the Dragon Boat at the Fifth Watch ballad.
He returned home, all amazed,
and he said:
“Such delicate music,
when such is produced in a place
then one cannot be (just) travel through.”
The Master told Yáo Yì 姚義 (dates uncertain, prominent young disciple, one of the presumed compilers of the Zhōngshuō 中說):
“Aren’t you going to enter politics?”
(Yáo) Yì said:
“As for discarding the Way and going after emoluments
I, for my part, have no time for that.”
The Master said:
“How earnest he is!”

Someone asked about Xún Yù 荀彧 (AD 163-212, highly admired follower of Cáo Cāo 曹操, advised in vain against the latter’s higher appointment and is said to have died of worry on behalf of his master) and Xún Yōu 荀攸 (AD 157-210, highly appreciated follower of Cáo Cāo 曹操, died for his master in a military campaign against Cáo Cāo’s rival Sūn Quán 孫權.).
The Master said:
“They are both worthy men.”
The questioner continued:
“How about their modes of living and of dying?”
The Master said:
“While living they sought to come to the rescue of their times;
through their death they illustrated the Way.
In the Xún family there were (these) two paragons of human-heartedness.”
The Master said:
“Speaking and showing good faith
is not as good as not speaking and showing good faith;
acting and showing diligence
is not as good as showing diligence without acting.”
Jiǎ Qióng said:
“How so?”
The Master said:
“Being earnest by reasoning things out (and deciding for silence)
one is faithful without speaking;
resting inactive by deciding to restrain oneself
one is diligent without acting.
Only someone who is possessed of the Way is capable of this.”
Yáng Sù 楊素 (died 606, poet and general, appointed Duke of Chǔ, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors), said to the Master:
Amazing
how the dresses, caps, underwear and footwear of the ancients
were unadorned and yet by no means convenient!”
The Master said:
“When the Former Kings made their laws on garments
weren’t they profound!
They made headwear in order to give dignity to their heads,
they made footwear in order to make their feet resilient.
Their upper and lower garments were neat,
their swords and belt-hangings were clanging properly,
and all this was designed to prevent undue haste:
that is why it was said to be dignified
and people looked up to these arrangements with reverence.
And in this way they (also) kept the common people from creating mischief.
but there still were those who were hastening unceremoniously in the roads.
Now they reject these things and say they are not convenient.
But this is to throw fish into deep water
or to put a monkey on a tree!
Then of course Everyone Under Heaven will inevitably rush about and play their crazy games!
It is because that by which they are guided is not the Way.”
Dǒng Cháng (favourite young disciple) was singing the Běibó Boat Song,
and when the Master heard this he said:
“It was Heaven who composed this!
What more can one say?”
Sū Wēi 蘇威 (the Duke of Péi ???????????) was fond of antiques:
bells, tripods, and all sorts of thing, round jade, seals, and coins, all thee he was sure to amass.
When the Master heard about this he commented:
“Those who liked old things in ancient times collected the Way,
those who like old things these days collect goods.”
The Master asked Zhòngzhǎng Zǐguāng 仲長子光 (date unknown, famous recluse and friend of Wáng Tōng as well as of his recluse-poet brother Wáng Jì 王績):
“Are mountain forests the places where one should live?”
Zhòngzhǎng Zǐguāng said:
“What by coincidence I run into is what I make do with.
How could I know whether this is what one should do?”
The Master commented:
“He really is someone who has got the point of things!
He lives as a recluse and speaks his mind freely!”
When (Zhòngzhǎng) Zǐguāng had left, he told Dǒng Cháng and Xuē Shōu (Wáng Tōng’s two familiar disciples):
“As for your Master (Wáng Tōng)
he is surely a perfect man!
Death or life are all the same to him:
he does not change for their sake.”
Xuē Shōu asked about living in hiding.
The Master said:
“The perfect man hides for reasons of Heaven,
the next best man hides for reasons of Earth,
the next best man hides for reasons of fame.”
The Master said that Yáo Yì (young disciple) was good at human relationships.
Someone said:
“That is his plain simplicity.”
The Master said:
“That is why he counts as capable.”
Someone else said:
“He is broad-minded.”
The Master said:
“Being broad-minded without going to excess,
that is another reason why he counts as capable.”
“Cháo Cuò 晁錯 (200-154 BC, important early Hàn ‘legalist’ thinker), was a leading figure in the attempt to revive the ancient Well Field System.
His ambition was to return to antiquity.”
Jiǎ Qióng asked about the duties in the Sequel to the Documents.
The Master said:
“There are duties for the Son of Heaven laid out in the Rules:
Official decision (zhì);
Public orders;
Public records;
Strategic documents.
There are seven duties laid out in the Yè “Official Duties” for senior ministers:
Commands;
Instructions;
Responses (to ruler’s questions);
Eulogies;
Public discussions;
Public warnings;
Admonitions. (i.e. critical representations to the ruler)
Wén Zhōngzǐ (i.e. the Master) said:
“As for the administrative system/régime of the (true) Emperor
it was vast and all-encompassing.
He surely had a comprehensive system of administration,
and administrated All Under Heaven, cutting nothing off (thus leaving it to others to deal with)!
Towards those above (the spirits) he was profoundly transparent,
towards those below he was serene.
When all under Heaven was in a precarious state
then he would bring peace to All Under Heaven;
when Everyone Under Heaven had got things wrong
then he would put things right for All Under Heaven.
‘Among all the changes and transformation
I constantly guard the course of the Mean.’
Overarching, he would not be moved!
In his responsiveness there surely was nothing to which he was not perceptive! This is called the régime of the Emperor.”
Wén Zhōngzǐ (i.e. the Master) said:
“The worries of the Changes
are all craintive
all preoccupied with things.
Surely the Changes are fearful of Heaven and full of sympathy for men,
when the thought is relevant to the times then one takes action (on the basis of the Changes)!”
Fán Shīxuān 繁師玄 (no dates, late Suí man of letters) said:
“This is so far-fetched/abstruse!
As for my viewing the Way in the Changes,
there is no such difficulty in it!”
The Master smiled and said:
“Is that so?
Strengthening oneself all day, that is the thing to do.
Your way of looking at (the Changes)is not good.
My reflections are not far-fetched/abstruse.”

Yáng Sù 楊素 (died AD 606, poet and general, also known as Duke of Yuè 越公, frequently mentioned member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors, though not really a disciple) was about to engage the Master on a formal mission.
The Master told his messenger (who arrived with presents):
“Keep these (presents) and be on your way!
And he sent him off while singing the Gānmáo Song (which describes the lavish reception of a worthy man, a xián rén 賢人).
Afterwards he said:
“What is jade and silk to me?!”
The Master said to Fāng Xuánlíng 房玄齡 (579 - 648, very famous politician and historian, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors):
“Loving success
is the basis for failure;
hoping for broadness
is the way towards narrowness.”
Fāng Xuánlíng said:
“(In that case: ) How is one going to be successful in words and deed?”
The Master said:
“What is necessary is to take realistic measure of one’s powers.”
The Master said:
Yáo Yì is someone to be friends with,
old agreements he will not neglect;
Jiǎ Qióng is someone to conduct business with,
in the face of difficulties he is unswerving;
Xuē Shōu one can serve a ruler with,
he is human-hearted and not glib-tongued.
Dǒng Cháng is someone to go out and stay with,
he is sturdy.” (=砎).
The Master said:
“Despising other creatures/people and setting high store by oneself
this is what the superior man will not do.
Going in for the extraordinary and appreciating the strange (=怪)
being extravagant and not knowing when to stop,
it must be a petty mind that goes with such attitudes.”
Xuē Hóng 薛宏 (details unknown) asked to have a look at the (Sequel to the) Six Classics.
but the Master would not give them away.
His entourage did not know what to think.
The Master smiled and said:
“Had there been a superior man fond of antiquity and of broad elegant culture,
then this would not have been something to keep to oneself.”
When a younger brother of his main wife died
the Master would not drink alcohol or eat meat.
When a compatriot criticised him for that
the Master said:
“It’s that I could not bear it.”
And then, reciting the last stanza of Racing Along, he left.

Zhèng Hé 鄭和 (no details available) maligned the Master to Yáng Sù 楊素 (died AD 606, poet and general, also known as Duke of Yuè 越公, frequently mentioned member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors, though not really a disciple):
“It was that man who has been impolite to you.
Why do you hold him in such high esteem?”
Yáng Sù sent someone to ask the Master about that.
The Master said:
“If you deserved to be treated impolitely
then, in all humility, I got it right;
if you did not deserve to be treated impolitely
then, in all humility, I’ve got it wrong.
Whether I got it right or wrong was all my problem,
why are you speculating about it?”
Yáng Sù continued to treat the Master as before.
The Master said:
“I have yet to meet any man who has courage of his own opinions.”
Someone said:
“Well, how about Hè Ruòbì 賀若弼 (554 -647, politician renowned for his courage under the Suí dynasty)?”
The Master said:
“As for Bì, he is the violent type,
how should he achieve courage?”
Lǐ Mì asked about heroes and lionhearts.
The Master said:
“He who understands himself is a hero;
and he who wins against himself is a lionheart.”
He asked about courage.
The master said:
“What is necessary for it is a just cause.”
Jiǎ Qióng (the disciple) said:
“Amazing, how All Under Heaven will not recognise your worth!”
The Master said:
“Well, do you want to know?
If you make a concise honest effort of cultivation,
even Heaven will recognise you,
how much more men!”
Jiǎ Qióng asked for a copy of the Sequel to the Six Classics,
and he said:
“I’m afraid our Master’s Way might go under.”
The Master said:
“It looks to me as if you are working for fame.
I have a beautiful jade and am waiting for a customer for it.”
Yáng Xuángǎn 楊玄感 (died AD 613, aristocratic military man) asked about filial piety.
The Master said:
“It begins with serving one’s parents,
and it ends with establishing oneself (to continue the heritage).
He asked about devoted effort.
The Master said:
“When filial piety is established then devoted effort will follow suit.”
Wèi Zhēng (580－643, famous intellectual and Taoist monk, marginal member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors) said:
“Does the sage have worries?”
The Master said:
“Everyone Under Heaven worries.
Should I alone get to the point where I do not worry?”
(Wèi Zhēng) asked about doubt.
The Master said:
“Everyone in All Under Heaven has his doubts.
Should I alone get to the point where I do not have my doubts?”
When (Wèi) Zhēng withdrew
the Master told Dǒng Cháng:
“Delighting in Heaven/Nature and understanding decreed fate
what worries should one have?
When one fully understands the principles of things and the nature of things,
what doubts should one have?
Dǒng Cháng said:
“This is by no means what you told Wèi Zhēng.
Surely you speak with two tongues.”
The Master said:
“What Wèi Zhēng asked about are the external symptoms,
what I am telling you is the heart of the matter.
There has long been a distinction between the heart of a matter and its external symptoms.
Could I alone speak with less than two tongues?”
Dǒng Cháng said:
“But is there a real difference between the heart of a matter and its external symptoms?”
The Master said:
“From your point of view they are different,
but someone one meets perchance would not understand the difference.
In each case one says what is appropriate to the audience, that is all!
So those two responses do not infringe the principle of speaking with one mind.”
Lǐ Bō 李播 (no date, mentioned as a friend of Wáng Tōng’s brother the poet Wáng Jì 王績) heard about this and sighed:
“What a great thing this unity is!
Everyone in All Under Heaven turns to it,
but they do not realise what they are doing.”
Chéng Yuán asked Wáng Níng 王凝 (Wáng Tōng’s younger brother) :
“That the Sequel to the Documents expresses Aspirations and Teachings.
what does that refer to?”
Wáng Níng told Wén Zhōngzǐ (Wáng Tōng) about this.
The Master said:
“The aspiration is to fully achieve the Way,
and the words are to make public these aspirations.
In the teachings one can surely see the aspirations of the true king,
his sympathy for others being all-embracing
and his reach being all-encompassing.
To one pronouncement All Under Heaven responds,
and a single public order cannot be changed.
Unless one is human-hearted, wise and broad-reaching
takes Heaven as his model and fully understands fate,
who can give lessons to Everyone Under Heaven?”
Wáng Níng said:
“May I ask what you mean by the term cè ‘strategy’?
The Master said:
“When statements have something canonical about them
their reach is broad;
when one sympathises with others and is not self-centered,
when one works hard and tirelessly
that surely is the proper strategy!”
The Master said:
The section Fate in the Sequel to the Documents is inscrutably profound,
it surely contains the general rules for relations between ruler and minister,
and it does fit the local conditions!
Surely, it comports success and failure in it,
everyone in All Under Heaven depends on it,
and, having no alternative, they live up to it!
In moving ahead, or moving backwards, in diminishing and growing,
they will not miss the right time.
The Way is very large,
and the creatures of the world will not abandon it.
But in rising high, setting out alone,
adapting to current constellations and going with the transformation of things,
one creates one’s own ‘decree of Heaven’!”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“As for one’s undertakings
it is surely when they make a choice in favour of human-heartedness and justice that there is proper planning!
Even the Son of Heaven must have a teacher
and yet, what constant teacher does he have
in whom the Way resides?
If he thinks in terms of persons of Everyone Under Heaven,
he accepts instruction from Everyone Under Heaven,
he achieves the Way of Everyone Under Heaven,
and he brings to completion the duties of Everyone Under Heaven,
and the common people do not understand where all this comes from:
that surely is an enlightened ruler!”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“For broadening one’s human-heartedness and increasing one’s wisdom
there is nothing more excellent that asking advice;
for getting on top of one’s tasks and for expounding the Way
there is nothing more excellent than answering questions.”
Who, other than an enlightened ruler, can put broad questions,
who, other than an accomplished minister, can give pointed answers to these?
When one generalises from what is appropriate
one will get everything right!
How superabundant they were,

these answers by Cháo Cuò 晁錯 (200-154 BC, important early Hàn ‘legalist’ thinker), Dǒng Zhòngshū 董仲舒 (179-104 BC, famous writer, philosopher and politician) and by Gōngsūn Hóng 公孫弘 (200 -121 BC, famous scholar official)!”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“If there is something beautiful and one does not make it known
what does Everyone Under Heaven have to look at?
The superior person, in relation to his ruler,
will praise his admirable points and politely correct his failings.
This is the way by which one promotes goodness, relentlessly,
and how, then, could there be less than peace in All Under Heaven?”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“Public discussion
surely aims at all the minds of Everyone Under Heaven!
In former times under the Yellow Emperor there was the listening in the Combined Palace (hé gōng),
under Yáo there was the questioning in the Crossroads Mansion (qū shì),
under Shùn there was the visiting the Western Hall (zǒng zhāng, in the famous míng táng 明堂 Palace),
and all this referred to public discussion.
Great indeed is the uniting of the plans of All Under Heaven!
When one the wisdom of each and everyone Under Heaven
one gets to the principles of things.
What is there left for one to do?
To make sure one strikes a respectful pose, facing south. That is all.”
The Master said:
“The core of man is precariously unstable,
and the core of the Way is subtle:
this means that the Way is hard to promote.
Therefore the superior person reflects on his faults and prepares to guard against them,
that is how he is on his guard;
he is incisive but not ad hominem;
he is meticulous (himself) but not resentful (about others failing to be);
when he is indirect he is not sycophantic
when he is straightforward he does observe the rules of ritual propriety:
Surely this is just ‘being on his guard’.”
The Master said:
“In correcting one’s mistakes one should be unstinting
and the blameless person is (actually only) one who is good at making up for his mistakes.
The enlightened kings of antiquity
how should they have been able to be without mistakes.
They followed remonstrations, that was all.
Thus a devoted minister’s service to his ruler
is to do one’s loyal best and to make up for mistakes.
When the ruler fails in his duty above
then the minister makes up for it below;
when the minister remonstrates below
then the ruler takes heed of these remonstrations above.
This is how the Way of the (ancient) kings does not stumble.
They take the ‘auspicious’ (moral instruction) from the ‘inauspicious’ (moral failures committed),
they exchange what is obfuscating for what is enlightening (cf棄暗投明)
without remonstration, who can reach high?”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“From Jìn dynasty times (AD 274-422) downwards
what a plethora of different rulers!
In my view Emperors Huì 晉惠帝 (AD 259-306) and Huái 晉懷帝 (AD 284-313) of the Jìn were upset about this (chaotic state of political affairs).
Apart from the Three Kingdoms, where could one place one’s aspirations?
But in the Three Kingdoms how they were out of their minds with worries!
In my view Emperors Huán 漢桓帝 (AD 132 - 167) and Líng 漢靈帝 (AD 156 - 189) of the Eastern Hàn were (properly) upset by this (political chaos),
but apart from the two Hàn dynasties, what was one to choose as a (political) system?”
The Master called the Tàihé administration (AD 477-499, in Northern Wèi) close to (the ideal of moral) elegance.
All at once it demonstrated that in the central states there is the rule of law.
It is such a pity
that they did not get to practise the Way of Duke (“Sir”?) Mù (Wáng Qiú 王虬 420 - 500, Duke Mù of Jìnyáng 晉陽穆公, Wáng Tōng’s ancestor who fled to the Northern Wèi but failed to make a major impact).”
Chéng Yuán (WT’s close disciple) said:
“What do you make of the Three Teachings?”
The Master said:
“In political administration it has long been the case that one hates there to be many factions.”
(Chéng Yuán) continued:
“How about abandoning them, then?”
The Master said:
“That is something you do not have the reach to understand!
The affairs of the Zhēnjūn (AD 440-451) and the Jiàndé AD 572 -578) eras (when Buddhism was forbidden, and Buddhist were persecuted)
came to make things worse.
they let loose the storms in an attempt to stop the fire.”
When the Master read the Honest Deliberations on Hóngfàn (皇極讜議 by his grandfather 安康獻公)
he exclaimed:
“The Three Teachings could at that point be united.”
Chéng Yuán and Wèi Zhēng (very famous intellectual, Taoist, and politician not naturally associated with WT’s less than illustrious disciple Chéng Yuán) stepped forward and said:
“What do you mean by that?”
The Master said:
“(The common point is to) cause the people not to tire of their tasks.”
Jiǎ Qióng was rehearsing the Sequel to the Documents,
and when he got to the Zhìyùn affair (CHECK)
he asked the Master:
May we ask about the distinctions between an Official Tasks, Commands, Aspirations, and an Administrative System?”
The Master said:
“Administrative Systems and Commands,
I have written about the proper way these have to be practised;
as for Aspirations and Public Tasks I have written about how these have to be moderated.”
Jiǎ Qióng told (WT’s elder brother) Wáng Níng about this.
Wáng Níng commented:
“Does not the Sequel to the Documents leave some things out?
In the Documents it says:
‘The only important point is excellence and unity,
in these one must take the middle path.’
Surely this refers to the Way!
In the Songs it says:
“We gather the fēng and the fēi
have no use for the lower parts.”
This surely refers to moderating restraint!”
When the Master heard about this (his brother exposing WT’s philological insouciances behind his back) he said:
“Our friend (Wáng) Níng does understand the (Sequel to the) Documents!”
The Master said:
“The relation of Public Tasks to Commands
is surely like the Aspirations having the Administrative System!
Unless human-heartedness and justice>morality comes from one’s inside
one cannot succeed.”
The Master said:
“When someone fully understanding the Way of administrative systems and public commands,
he will surely understand the work of kings and dukes,
and he will surely get to the essence/heart of the transformations (in this world)!
When someone fully understands the Way of Aspirations and of Public Tasks
then he will surely understand the difficulties in the relations between rulers and ministers,
and he will get the ultimate point of human-heartedness and justice!”
The Master said:
“If one dwells in poverty and in humble surroundings without fear
one may become rich and noble;
when one’s boy servants are praising one’s generosity
then one can conduct political administration;
when one’s travel companions praise one’s good faith
then one can produce meritorious results.”
The Master said:
“If one loves (public personal) fame and sets high store by (private personal) profit
then what a petty man one is!
I have yet to see a human-hearted person who is fond of fame and profit.”
Jiǎ Qióng asked about the Way of the superior person.
The Master said:
“To reverse this was something I could not imagine
and yet now it is all over.” (Karlgren)
When the Master saw someone wearing mourning garment and wailing all the time
he paid his condolence to him (assuming the death to have been recent).
He asked when the death had occurred,
and the mourner said:
“Five years ago.”
With tears in his eyes the Master said:
“One must not go beyond the system of regulations of the Former Kings.”
The Yáng Xuángǎn 楊玄感 (died AD 613, Yáng Sù’s 楊素 son) asked about the Way to follow a teacher in one’s practice.
The Master said:
“Conduct matters in accordance in the spirit of human-heartedness and justice>your moral values.”
Yáng Xuángǎn continued:

and the petty man hopes for his (kind of) generous treatment (as evidenced in WT’s actions).
Wáng Níng (WT’s brother)said:
“As for my attitude to the Way of the Former Kings
while walking I reflect on it, when sitting I recite it
but I always feel as if I am getting nowhere;
when it comes to comings and goings of concrete action
I always feel as if I have got no instruction.
The Way is really hard!”
The Master said:
“I feel the same way.”
Wáng Níng said:
“Everyone Under Heaven hates straightforwardness and finds correctness ugly,
can I alone find my acquiesce in these things?”
The Master cut a sad face and he said:
So shall the Spirits hearken to you,
And give you large measures of bright happiness. SHI 207
The superior person’s relation to the Way
only stops at his death.
Heaven does not stop blowing cold and hot because men hate these and heave their sighs,
and the superior person does not stop his correct and straight behaviour because others find that ugly and hate it.
Have you not heard the word from the Hóngfàn?
Be even, frank, correct and straight.
Because one is like this
one gets away unscathed.
Now you are fidgeting about
you base yourself on none of the Three Virtues
and your mind is not solidly established.
Never to stand straight,
never to attack malfeasance,
never to be firm
never to resist injustice,
this is to be wrong-headed.
And so if the people (that you are responsible for) misbehave,
is that not your own fault?”
Wáng Níng bowed twice and left.
Chóu Zhāng 關吏仇璋 (Pass Magistrate,no further details known, became a disciple) stepped forward and said:
“When the superior man reflects so as to treat others with respect
is there honesty in this?”
The Master smiled and did not reply.
Xuē Shōu said:
“The superior man will only smile when delighted.
Why should our Master not side with the one who here stepped forward.”
The Master said:
“(As the Documents have it:) Even a crazy person can come to think properly,
is not that a case for delight?”
The Master said to Chóu Zhāng 關吏仇璋 (Pass Magistrate, no further details known from other books, became a disciple) and to (his disciple) Xuē Shōu:
“The difficult thing is not the understanding of things,
it is only the putting it into practice.”
Wèi Zhēng said:
“In the Documents it says:
'Accordance with the right leads to good fortune;
following what is opposed to it, to bad -
the shadow and the echo.'
“In the Songs it says:
are they not concordant, are they not respectful,
will they not receive much happiness!
While it passes from one to another, they show no pride.
All blessings must come to seek them.”
This is surely to the point!”
The Master said:
“You are able yourself to pick your own good fortune.”
Dǒng Cháng said:
“But if one makes one’s own pick, will this fit in with other people?”
The Master said:
“Indeed!
These things are nothing other than what man have been asking for.”
Jiǎ Qióng stepped forward and said:
“May I (then!) ask about
‘For birth and death there is decreed fate,
wealth and honour depend on Heaven.’
What does this really mean?”
The Master said:
“You’ve been asking for it first,
and the fate comes afterwards,
this is to make your own pick,
how should this not be decreed fate?
Ah!
I really can do nothing about it!”
Jiǎ Qióng bowed and left
and then he told Chéng Yuán:
“From now on I understand that one’s decreed fate can be created
and that great good fortune can be sought for oneself.”
Chéng Yuán said:
“The admired jade words
I take them to heart and will never tire of them.” *[[[Note the subtle variations in the allusions.]]]
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“Taking virtue as a standard for the choice of teachers,
exchanging children for instruction,
these practices have discontinued.”
The Master said:

“If one fails to use the ways of Yī Yǐn 伊尹 (early Shāng dynasty senior minister) and of the Duke of Zhōu 周公 (11th cent. BC, crucial figure in the foundation of the Zhōu dynasty, also referred to as Duke Dàn of Zhōu 周公旦) to give peace to one’s country
then one is not a great minister.

Those who not serve one’s ruler with the attitudes of Huò Guāng (ca.130 - 68 BC, powerful politician) and of Zhūgé Liàng 諸葛亮 (181 - 234, legendarily loyal and capable minister in the Romance of the Three Kingdoms),
are mere place-holder ministers.”
Dǒng Cháng sighed and said:
“How fine
the attitude was of Yánzǐ (Yán Huí 顏回).
For three months in a row he never offended against human-heartedness.”
When the Master heard about this he said:
“Human-heartedness is surely not far away.
By thinking about it even for a moment one practises it.
You praise him for good reason!
If only you concentrate your mind
you then ascend a high bank (scil. so as to have a broad perspective on things).
As he left, Dǒng Cháng said:
“In one’s planning one does not reach the subtle truth,
in one’s reflections one does not attain to wisdom,
how can one come to be without blame?
How can one fail to offend?”
Fán Shīxuān 繁師玄 (no dates, late Suí man of letters, author of an historical work about the Northern Qí dynasty) heard that Dǒng Cháng was talented.
He asked Jiǎ Qióng how old he was.
Jiǎ Qióng said:
“I’ve just been capped (i.e. is 20 years old).”
Fán Shīxuán said:
“Oh! A junior prodigy!”
Jiǎ Qióng said:
“The Master was a teacher to others at the age of fifteen.
Wáng Xiàoyì 王孝逸 (Suí official active in the 580ies) from Chénliú
was an arrogant man who gained a fine understanding at an early age,
and still at his white-haired age he treats the Master as his teacher.
That surely was not on account of his age!
I’ve heard it said:
‘Virtue is not a matter of seniority,
the Way is not a matter of social position.’”
A follower asked Yáo Yì 姚義 (dates uncertain, prominent young disciple, one of the presumed compilers of the Zhōngshuō 中說):
“The laws in the Confucius family
were the Songs and the Rituals.
And he did not refer to the Four Classics.
Why was that?
Yáo Yì said:
“I have heard it from the Master:
the judging of things in the Annals
one only gets to after one’s spiritual orientation is fixed;
the Ritual Music serves harmony
one only gets to after them one’s virtue has become comprehensive;
the Documents are for the systematic establishment of laws,
and one only gets to them after one has got to work in public employment.
the Changes serve to give accounts of underlying principles,
and one only gets to them after one understands decreed fate.
And so, without studying the Annals
one does not have the means to make proper judgements,
without studying the Documents
one does not have the means to discuss political systems;
without studying the Changes
one does not have the means to have a pervasive understanding of principles.
Without these four being available
the intellectual realisation of these things cannot be reached.
That is why the sage delays things (until disciples have studied these books).
They are not just paedagogical tools for use in teaching the young.”
Someone said:
“Why is it that the Songs and the Rituals come first?”
Yáo Yì replied:
“If one teaches the Songs
then one brings out the force of the formulations
and in this way one keeps insensitivity and informality at bay;
if one constrains people with Ritual
then one will move their public appearance
and in this way one will establish their authority and seriousness.
They will measure their words,
they will consider carefully their aspirations,
they will check their comportment,
they will consider critically their virtue.
When their aspirations have been fixed they will enunciate them through the Annals,
and at that point they will have settled things and can adapt to changes in the situations;
when their virtue is comprehensive it will guide them through Ritual Music,
and at that point they will be harmonious and understand moderation.
When they are in a position to engage in public work
they guide them to understanding through the Documents,
and at that point they can establish a system for themselves;
when they understand their decreed fate one expands their minds through the Changes
and at that point one can exhaustively understand the nature of things with them.
If one springs the Annals on them abruptly,
then they will become profligate in their aspirations and think little of justice;
if one springs the Music on them abruptly
then one will make hollow declarations on virtue and ruin the proper measure;
if one springs the Documents on them abruptly
then they will have an inappropriately informal attitude to the law;
if one springs the Changes on them abruptly
then they will indulge in spiritual games.
Thus the sage will understand the inner necessity of things,
he will therefore establish things on the basis of general principle,
and arrange them in their proper order.
He will first get things completed in himself
before he provides for other things;
he will first sort things out close at hand
before he gives them shape far on the outside.
Indeed, these things are profound!
Indeed, these things are profound!”
When the Master heard about this he said:
“Our friend Yáo Yì has got the point!”
The Master said:
“If one’s real knowledge is less than one displayed brilliance,
or if one’s real virtue is slighter than one’s practical talent,
then one is definitely getting things wrong.”
The Master said:
“Good order and chaoscome in cycles:
There are those who avail themselves of these cycles
and there are those who change these cycles.
Being cornered and winning through is a matter of opportunity:
There are those who act on these things
and there are those who run into them.
Auspiciousness and inauspiciousnessare a matter of decreed fate.
There are those who create these things,
and there are those who run into them by chance.
One of these comes, the other goes,
all arrive in due course.
They clearly are not there for nothing!”
During the military campaign in Liáodōng (614, failed military campaign by Emperor Yáng of the Suí 隋煬帝 against Gāolì 高麗 in Korea)
Everyone Under Heaven was building ships.
The Master commented:
“The timber is all gone.
If the emperor goes on a tour of inspection in the mountains
how is one to put things to reply to his questions?”
Somebody asked about the Sequel to the Classics.
Xuē Shōu and Yáo Yì (disciples) told the Master about this.
The Master said:
“Supposing a talented person criticises wickedness
then one will make shine forth the sincere truth so as to answer questions,
but when a stupid person criticises evil
then what is one to do?”
And then he incanted the last stanza of the Shǔlí in the Songs
and he went in to his entourage and said:
“As for the matter of the five types of association and the three reasons for dissociation

Liú Xiàobiāo 劉孝標 (AD 462-521, legendary book-lover and unsuccessful official, also often referred to as Liú Jùn 劉峻, author of the highly original Guǎng jué jiāo lùn 廣絕交論 which expounds five types of social relations: 勢交,賄交,談交,窮交,量交 and three types of dissociation from others: 敗德殄義,仇訟所聚,名陷饕餮) surely does know how to express himself.”
Fāng Xuánlíng asked:
“When something is good then to praise the ruler
when there has been a mistake then to blame oneself,
may that be called devoted effort?
The Master said:
“(Well:) That way one is being polite to others.”
Dù Rúhuì 杜如晦 (585-630, senior minister in the early Táng administration) asked about political administration.
The Master said:
“Promote your earnestness,
put forward your good example;
reward one in order to encourage one hundred,
fine one in order to punish a whole crowd.
What problem will you have then in political administration?”
Dù Rúhuì left
and he told Dòu Wēi 竇威 (died 618, important early Táng politician):
“From an honest fellow to put up with injustice,
but as for flatterers to block their designs:
there is reward and punishment in these practices.
I’ve got a good idea about conducting government.”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“Regarding the System and Decreed Fate I do not go as far as the Huángchū period (AD 220 - 226);
regarding ambitions and undertakings I did not go as far as the Tàixī period (AD 290)
regarding praise and blame I did not go as far as the Rénshòu period (AD 601 - 604).”
Wáng Níng said:
“What do you mean?”
The Master said, despondently,
“(The idea is that) as for the period between the Rénshòu period (AD 601 - 604) and the Dàyè period (AD 605 - 617)
Do I have words for the events of that time?”
Jiǎ Qióng asked:
“Make the people well off and then teach them, (LY)
what does that mean?”
The Master said:
“Human-heartedness arises under conditions of indigence
justice arises from affluence.
Therefore if you teach them on the basis of prosperity
that is easy.
In ancient times the sage kings were in charge,
fields and villages were adjoining each other,
cocks and dogs heard each other (such was the density of the population).
People reached their old age and their death without any interaction.
This was presumably because they were self-sufficient.
And so in the age of perfect good governance
the Five Cardinal Texts were hidden
the five rituals were eschewed,
the five official garments were not displayed.
People knew how to drink and eat,
and they did not know how to cover up and hide;
people knew how to live in groups
and they did not know how to care for and respect each other.
Those in charge were like dangling twigs,
those below were like wild deer.
Why was that?
Presumably because those in charge practised (the art of) inaction
and because those below were self-sufficient.
Jiǎ Qióng said:
After that pristine simplicity has been dispersed
can it come back?”
The Master said:
“Man can make the Way predominant:
when he gets to the right practices
that is as easy as turning one’s palm around.
In former times Shùn and Yǔ 禹 followed the proven ways and Everyone Under Heaven was in pristine simplicity,
when Jiè of the Xià 夏桀 dynasty (last emperor of the Xià dynasty) continued this tradition, Everyone Under Heaven turned fraudulent.
When Tāng the Successful 成湯 (founder of the Shāng dynasty) ousted Jié 桀 (last emperor of the Xià dynasty) All Under Heaven was pacified,,
but when Zhòu of the Shāng dynasty 殷紂 (last emperor of the Shāng dynasty) took over Everyone Under Heaven was in uproar.
Under Wén and Wǔ (early Zhōu dynasty rulers) there was good order, and under Yōu and Lì there was disintegration.

Under Wén (Emperor Wén of the Hàn 漢文帝 (202 - 157 BC)) and Jǐng (Emperor Jǐng of the Hàn 漢景帝 (reigned 157 - 141 BC)) there was peace, and under Huán (Emperor Huán of the Eastern Hàn 漢桓帝 (AD 132 - 167))and Líng (Emperor Líng of the Eastern Hàn 漢靈帝 (AD 156 - 189) there was failure.
In this way good order and chaos replace each other,
murkiness and purity have their reasons.
Flourishing and demise are aided by men,
success and failure depend on teaching.
When one says that the age of high antiquity cannot be brought back
this is not to show a proper understanding of the transformations of (the system of) the Former Kings.
Then the Songs, Documents, Rituals and Music
what would they be good for?”
Dǒng Cháng heard about this
and he told Jiǎ Qióng:
“After the pronouncements of Confucius and of Mencius were no more,
and the Way of the Master is practised,
then that is a case of When one gives them peace they flock to one,
when one drives them into action they will be in harmony with each other.
Who ever said that the pristine simplicity is not something one can revert to.”
The Master said:
“Few are those who sort out their emotional reactions on the basis of their inborn nature.
And I have yet to see anyone who is not in doubt at cross-roads.
The Changes say:
He is straight, square and great,
So without working at it
will not fail to be fitting.
And so he has no doubts about what he is doing.
Dòu Wēi (died AD 618, important early Táng politician) said:
“How great
is the way in which the Changes exhaust the nature of things.
Who of our people lives up to this?”
The Master said:
“Dǒng Cháng (favourite disciple) comes close, though.”
Somebody asked:
“Dòu Wēi and Dǒng Cháng,
how do you rate them relative to each other?
The Master said:
“I don’t know.”
The Master said:
Wēn Dàyǎ 溫大雅 (dates unknown, Suí dynasty official, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors) seems to have come close to the Way,
I suppose he is a recluse.
Remaining silent he achieves success,
without speaking he inspires trust.”
Someone asked about Tāo Yuánliàng (Táo Yuānmíng 陶淵明 (AD 365 - 427, great poet).
The master said:
“He was a dissolute character.
In his Guī qù lái there is an attitude of lying low in one’s land,
and as for the Account of Mr Five Willows
it comes close to closing oneself off (from the world).”
The Master said:
“One who has harmonised his great resentments is bound to have residual resentments;
one who disregards great pleasures is bound to have residual pleasures.
Such is the Way of Heaven.”
The Master said:
“The vital energy is primary,
physical manifestation (of it) is secondary.
When awareness dwells on these,
then the Heaven, Earth and Man are all on hand.
The vital energy is the “ghost”
I is surely Heaven!
Awareness is the “spirit”,
that is surely Man!
I have found the underlying principles and the nature in these.”
Xuē Shōu said:
“May I ask as to the ‘spirits of Heaven’ and the ‘ghosts of men’,
what do these refer to?
Did the Duke of Zhōu 周公 (11th cent. BC, crucial figure in the foundation of the Zhōu dynasty, also referred to as Duke Dàn of Zhōu 周公旦) have a grasp of these?”
The Master said:
“Great indeed
was the Duke of Zhōu!
What was distant he darkly understood in his mind.
The mind is nothing other than this:
what seeks to get to the bottom of principles.
Therefore that mind is entirely based in Heaven.
It pushes the spirit towards Heaven.
(The mind) honours Heaven, while keeping at a distance from it.
That is why it connects with Heaven through the rituals of the sì sacrifice.
Close at hand the mind seeks the truth in itself.
And as for the Self, it is nothing other than this:
it is the complete development of one’s nature.
In the end one subsumes it under the ‘person’.
When one transfers features from the supernatural beings to persons,
then by extension (from the spirits) one venerates these persons (after their death)???.
And so one keeps in contact with them by public entertainment rituals.
In ancient times one was an observer (only) at the wine-sacrifice and did not attend the bloody sacrifices.
This showed more than half-way successful reflection.”
Xuē Shōu said:
“May I ask about the spirits of the earth?”
The Master said:
“These are perfect indeed!
All kinds of creatures are born from it (Earth),
the myriad species take their form from it.
Making this manifest to the people
that is the meaning of the spirits of the earth.
As for the physical body
it is nothing other than this:
it refers to the bones and the flesh of something.
And so one relates to the body through the jì sacrifice.
Xuē Shōu said:
“To which of these three do you give priority?”
The Master said:
“Heaven, Earth, and Man are inseparable,
but when placed in the context of concrete practice
then there is (always) one that dominates.
In the case of the altar where one sacrifices to Heaven, the priority is to the sì sacrifice.
One observes the Way of the spirits.
In the case of the sacrifices to the local deities one sets highest store by the jì sacrifice
and one observes the categories of material offerings.
In the case of the ancestral temples one employs the spirit-entertainment ritual
and one is mindful of the subtle vital energies.”
Xuē Shōu said:“May I ask about the basic significance of Heaven, Earth and Man?”
The Master said:
“Perfect indeed, this question!”
As for Heaven,
it organises the primal vital energies,
and this does not just refer to the vast azure sky;
as for Earth,
this organises the primal physical shapes,
and this does not just refer to mountains and rivers, hills and mounds;
as for man,
he organises the primal awareness
an this is not just refer to him having a round head and rectangular feet.
The significance of the hexagrams for Heaven and Earth,
have you thought about these?”
At this point Xuē Shōu withdrew and studied the Changes (which begin with explanations of the hexagrams for Heaven and Earth).
The Master said:
“Archery served to let one observe virtue,
but nowadays this practice has disappeared.
In ancient times they set high store by human-heartedness and justice,
they despised bravery and physical strength.”
The Master said:
Those who reject virtue and turn their backs on justice,
and who then are upset that others do not show them affection,
who love to be suspicious and go in for fraudulence
and who then are upset that others do not trust them:
such people do exist!”
The Master said:
“When the superior person wins over the minds of others,
he is not winning verbal battles against them;
(for) if one wins verbal battles against others
one is not subduing their persons.
subduing another person
is a matter of applying force to them.
The superior person uses rectitude as a means,
the petty person uses power as a means.
It is all difficult, isn’t it!”
The Master said:
After Tàixī (AD 290)
what remained of the Son of Heaven was only that designation.
Alas!
If (as a standard for deserving the designation “Son of Heaven”) one looks to transforming things so as to bring them into line through political administration,
then a even barbarian ruler will live up to the standard.
There was every reason for the Primal Classic to become a success.
Fāng Xuánlíng 房玄齡 (AD 579 - 648, very famous politician and historian) said to Xuē Shōu:
“That the Way won’t be practised is just inevitable.
Why does our Master make such a fuss about this?”
Xuē Shōu said:
“Aren’t you a follower of our Master?
When the Son of Heaven loses the Way
then the feudal lords will cultivate it;
when the feudal lords lose the Way
then the senior dignitaries will cultivate it;
when the senior dignities lose the Way
then the scholars will cultivate it;
when the scholars lose the Way
then the ordinary people will cultivate it.
The method of cultivating things
is to follow a master, but not always the same master,
to teach the Way tirelessly,
to get to the bottom of things without being excessive,
and to press on until one dies.
When one gets a chance, then to act on it,
when one has not a chance, then to curl up
this is the means by which the Way of the Former Kings continued their line and did not decline.
In ancient times one called this ‘following through opportunities that present themselves’.
Does not the Song say:
Even though I have not gone (to you),
why have I heard nothing from you? (SHI 91)
Why should one give up just because one’s ideas are not being put into practice?”
Fāng Xuánlíng thanked him respectfully:
“Surely, putting one’s ideas into practice is so far off!”
The Master said:
“When the central states lose the Way
the Four Barbarians know what is going on.”
Wèi Zhēng 魏徵 (A.D. 580－643, famous intellectual and Taoist monk, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors) said:
“May I ask for an explanation?”
The Master said:
“When the Little Elegances (of the Songs) were all given up,
the Four Barbarians were making their joined inroads:
this was because the central states had lost the Way.
Is that not the right explanation?”
Wèi Zhēng withdrew and told Xuē Shōu:
“It is possible to understand when opportunities arise!”
Xuē Shōu asked:
“Why do people nowadays have no Folk Songs.”
The Master said:
“Folk songs
are a matter of the emotional nature of the people.
How could the emotional nature of the people disappear?
It isn’t that the people have no folk songs,
it is the fault of those who administer the collection of lyrical poetry.”
Yáo Yì 姚義 (dates uncertain, prominent young disciple, one of the presumed compilers of the Zhōngshuō 中說) was suffering extreme poverty.
Fāng Xuánlíng 房玄齡 (AD 579 - 648, very famous politician and historian) said:
“How sad,
those difficulties!
Why not ask for help?”
Yáo Yì said:
“When in former times one asked for help on behalf of others
one would still take that to be a failure of politeness.
How much more (of a failure of politeness is it) when asking for help for oneself!
I have no intention to ask for help!”
When the Master heard about this he said:
“How meticulous, his sense of justice!
He is the one who practises the Way of the ancients.
He is an inspiration for me:
It is hard to make progress but easy to pull back (on this kind of moral path).”
The Master said:
“Even in concrete observations on things close at hand there is bound to be something to be investigated,
when one seeks out what they are based on, they (may) have far-reaching significance.”
Wáng Guī 王珪 (AD 570 - 639, powerful politician, given name 叔玠) asked for a copy of the Sequel of the Classics from the Master.
The Master said:“My uncle,
what virtue of mine is therein deployed?”
Wáng Guī said:
“Don’t be so apologetic about it!
When facing a question of goodness one does not defer (even) to one’s teacher, LY 15.36
how much less so when there is no teacher!
I have heard about a divination by Guān Láng (fl. ca. 500, famous specialist of the Changes. Often referred to as Guān Zǐmíng 關子明. See details in Zhang Pei p. 213.):
After continued chaos
a great worthy will be born.
As for the practice of ritual propriety and ritual music for generations on end
no one surpasses our clan.
Heaven has not yet destroyed the Way:
the one who can shake this civilisation to life again
if it is not the you, Sir, who is it?”
Wèi Zhēng 魏徵 (AD 580－643, famous intellectual and Taoist monk, member of Wáng Tōng’s group of visitors and interlocutors) asked:
“As for discussing public matters in terms of the overall system,
what do you think of that?”
The Master said:
“When one really straightens out the basis
physical punishments will be discontinued at that point.
When one has lost the right Way
what use is it to discuss it publicly?
Thus in an age of supreme good government
laws hang over people and are not offended against,
the next best thing is for them to be offended against, but not often.
That is why one discusses public affairs in terms of the overall system.
Ah!Ours is an age in-between the ages (Uebergangszeitalter).
If there were someone to employ me
there certainly would not be any public litigation.”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“After the pacification of Chén (AD 588, by the Suí)
the Dragon Virtue rose high (at which point the Changes prescribe “regret”).
but to the end there were no regrets (and the lesson of the Changes was not taken).
How sad!”
The Master said:
“When it comes to the Sequel to the Document and to the Primal Classic,
these surely represent an understanding of decreed fate.
I felt sad about ritual propriety and ritual music and compiled the Chapters on Ritual and the Records on Music;
I corrected the calendrical numbers and decided between the South and the North
I was moved by the imperial system and started with the Tàixī era (AD 290),
I honoured the central states and counted the years from Huángshǐ era (AD 396-398).”????
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“When one is activist, one’s mistakes will be multifarious;
when one remains inactive one’s mistakes will be few.”
The Master said:
“There is no greater crime than love of advancement,
and there is no greater disaster than that of talking too much;
there is no greater pain than that of failing to hear of one’s mistakes,
and there is no greater disgrace than failing understand one’s shameful points.”
Xuē Shōu asked Zhòngzhǎng Zǐguāng 仲長子光 (dates unknown, famous recluse and friend of Wáng Tōng as well as his his recluse-poet brother Wáng Jì 王績) about political administration.
Zǐguāng said:
“When raising one main line
all the holes get larger;
when you relax one trigger
all undertakings collapse.
I do not understand the proper administration of things.”
Xuē Shōu told Wén Zhōngzǐ about this.
The Master said:
“Zǐguāng had it right.”
Wén Zhōngzǐ said:
“If one does not understand the Way
then one has not the means to become a proper minister,
how much less a proper ruler!”
The Master said:

Books of sages, official garments or ritual instruments he would never borrow.

in his relations with others he was not ostentatiously pliant

he would never wear anything or eat it.

saying: ‘if it matches up to ritual propriety that will do.
When he lived at home he did not eat meat
saying: ‘one should not seek eating to the full.
His one blanket he did not change once in twenty years.
saying: ‘one should never make expenses at the cost of All Under Heaven’.
When among his neighbours someone was cheating on his taxes
he would pay twice in one year for him.
When taking up office he would count the days and receive emoluments according to the exact number of days he had been on duty.
When he was over seventy

but he never touched upon other people’s weak points.
He always had the look of someone who could do no wrong.
